NOTE: I don't play Multiplayer

HISTORY

Age of Empires II is the greatest Real Time Strategy game ever made. It was releases in 1999 and I've played it ever since. In 2013 we finally got the HD edition - a modern version of the game to be played through Steam. In 2015 and 2016 we got more expansion packs and finally in 2019 we got a total remake of the entire game in this glorious Definitive Edition. Every year since we've received 1-2 DLCs/year, and the first for 2024 has just been announced - it's insane!

The love for this game from both community and developers is one of a kind and I've never seen such massive dedication before, maybe with the exception of Remedy Entertainment. Playing AoE 2 DE in 2024 is the best it has ever been, 25 years later. How is this possible?!

All the DLCs have something to offer and there's none that I wouldn't recommend.

GAMEPLAY

The game is simple. Crush your enemies by any means necessary. Sometimes the campaigns have other goals as well and the 300+ scenarios are deeply varied. This is most likely the longest RTS game ever made, but since the scenarios are all self contained it never feels boring.

You mix your tactics with both economy where you build a city and fortresses as well as gathering the 4 resources of food, gold, stone and wood. Everything you do will cost resources from one or more of these 4 basic ingredients. The rest is up to you.

This game gives you total freedom like no other game for infinite replay value. You can also challenge yourself by increasing the difficulty level or hunt for any of the Steam Achievements.

This game is absolutely amazing and stands the test of time after 25 years. It's the best strategy game ever made and can be enjoyed by young and old alike.
It's survived the test of time.

This edition of the game truly makes everything come together. This is one of the best RTS of all times, and the Forgotten team is trying to make sure it will not be forgotten (lol).
[h2]The good points[/h2]
[list]
[*]The graphics are good without requiring a powerful machine and are still faithful to the original game.
[*]All the original campaigns are here, with some modifications to try to balance them.
[*]3+ years after the release, we can say that this version is the most responsive we ever had, there are still pathing issues and such but the game does feel good to play.
[*]The game has a ranked system for the ones who want to go competitive. It is not the best ranked system of all times, but it does work. There is also a OK lobby system to organize games with your friends.
[/list]
[h2]The bad points[/h2]
[list]
[*]The settings page of the game is horrible, the keybindings reset for no reason and you need external websites to set them up correctly.
[*]Each official update is a mess and introduces a lot of bugs. Be prepared to be unable to play the game for 1 week each time.
[*]DLC contents are... questionable?
[/list]
This is a really good game, and the best version of this game. But be aware that it can be a bit janky sometimes.

I began playing Age of Empires 2: Age of Kings with my late father in 2008, when I was six years old. He loves AOE2, and in fact, AOE2 is the second PC video game I've played (the first being C&C Red Alert 2), and I've been playing it for years. Then, in 2011 (I think), my late father purchased AOE2 The Conqueror, which I still like and play on occasion. 

Fast forward to 2020, when the COVID-19 quarantine occurred, I was 18 years old, and I received my first laptop. Having suddenly remembered this game after a long time, I let my late father play it, and he did so just as he did back in 2008 when he first introduced me to AOE2. He passed away on July 20, 2021, and I believe this was the final video game he played (that I am aware of). I'm still missing him. This is a "forever game" for me. And, as embarrassing as it is to admit, this tiny RTS video game has somehow stuck with me after all this time.

I initially wrote a short gushing review, but now that I've played it more I have mixed feelings. I'll try to give you enough information to make your own decision.

The good:
- it's a very deep RTS with lots of interesting viable strategies and randomly generated maps keeping every game fresh
- many QoL improvements over the original AoE2: you can shift-click to queue multiple commands for a unit, you can attack-move, there's control groups (aka unit bookmarks), there's a global production queue, etc
- there's matchmaking! with a big community so you can usually get matched in about 2 minutes. with someone of the same skill.
- you can spectate live matches in-game, which is a nice way to enjoy the game without the stress or commitment of actually playing.
- balance improvements over the original, such as much-needed buffs to melee infantry
- very strong AI opponents. in most RTS games (including original AoE2) the hardest AI setting is just the second-hardest with a massive artificial advantage, but in this game it plays fair. it plays like a human in so many ways you wouldn't expect. it's very tough, and rewarding to beat.

the YMMV:
- music. i'll always miss the original music from my childhood. thankfully, most of the definitive edition's music is remixes and new tracks rather than removed tracks, but I wold still rather the originals, especially the main menu music.

the bad:
- horrible unit pathfinding. it is so common and so frustrating to lose games because your units just go the fucking opposite direction as you order them, or they just get stuck and can't attack anything. villagers take the long way around obstacles for no reason, and get stuck on each other, or just stuck on thin air, and forget their task and go idle.
- lots of other in-game bugs. town bell (tells your villagers to hide from attackers) not working properly. villagers ordered to build a wall sometimes skip a tile for some reason, letting the enemy in. etc.
- lots of out-of-game bugs too. lobbies bug out. menus bug out. and when the menus aren't bugging out, they're the laggiest thing in the known universe for some reason (the game itself does not lag).
- they removed LAN multiplayer :(
- questionable monetization. they're selling DLC civs, so you can face people in ranked games who are playing civs you can't. it's not necessarily pay to win because the DLC civs aren't blatantly stronger than the base ones, but up to you how annoying that is. they're also hella overpriced for a game that already costs money.

I should've reviewed this a long time ago. My first foray into the Age of Empires series (and RTS games in general) was through the original version of AoE2 around 2003 or so.

After AoE3, the series sort of went dormant for a long time, so I was surprised to find out about the HD Edition and then the Definitive Edition releasing within the past decade. There has been a lot of content and QoL improvements added to AoE2 since it's original release, and the franchise has experienced a much-deserved revival as of late.

This fan-favorite game is a classic that has been really fun for the past 25+ years, and should still be fun for the next 25+ years or more.

I have been playing Age of Empires II since 1999.  It remains one of my favorite gaming experiences.  All the core RTS elements are present, but the rock/paper/scissor gameplay is unmatched. Without a doubt the core DE game and Return of Rome are the best value if you can't afford every DLC.  That provides you with the majority of the game's civilizations as well as access to the updated and most playable version of the original Age of Empires. The depth to this game is endless, with each civilization feeling a little bit different and allowing the player to tackle scenarios in distinct ways.  Perhaps the only downside is the sheer breadth of the game for those starting out.  The original release of Age of Empires II had 13 civilizations, but now, if you purchase every DLC, there are 45! This is great for people who have kept up with the game, but may seem overwhelming trying to discover every civ bonus and identity if you are new to the series.  Too much content is rarely an issue, but for anyone considering the competitive scene it may be tough to get your feet under you.  All in all, however, this is one of those rare near perfect games.  For me it is a 10/10.

And even while I got it on release and then did not play it more than 10 hours until now, I consumed low triple digits of Age of Empires 2 DE version content in that time, watching commented replays or tournaments. And this IS the definitive AoE2 experience currently available. I consider the original release and the HD release time capsules of the same game and this is the up to date version. I enjoyed this game since 1999 as a kid and I love it still. Full recommendation from me, one of the greatest games of all time to me

The legendary AOE2 endures. Released in the "golden era" of the classic RTS, AOE2 is still around. And not only is it still around, its doing better than ever. Very rarely do we see a company, especially as big as Microsoft, take good care of their IPs. But that's exactly what they did with AOE2. And the care shows. The community is still around. Not only has AOE2 endured, but it's thriving. It makes me so happy to see this. Not only because AOE2 is my childhood, but happy to see a company treat such a legendary game with respect. This is the result - a thriving, engaged community, and a budding e-sport. I see the community on youtube. I see them engaged, I see them excited. It's incredible to watch.

Contrast this to Blizzard, who mishandled and destroyed Warcraft, completely disrespecting and looting the small Warcraft 3 playerbase with their botched release of Reforged. No apology, nothing. Just greed and disrespect. Warcraft, the IP that put Blizzard on the map. 

It makes me so happy to see AOE2 thriving. This is a proper update to the game, modernizing the engine, updating the graphics but keeping the aesthetic true to the original, and expanding the game just enough for new content and for new players. Well done Microsoft, well done. People can hate on Microsoft all they want, but whoever is handling AOE2 knows exactly what they are doing, and more importantly, they respect AOE2 for the venerable, legendary game that it is, and recognizes the potential it has for being a little bit of an e-sport of it's own.

May AOE2 last forever.

The game is a great refresher of the classical 1999. release and the later HD release which it trump in asthetics and features.

The good:
The population increase allows incredible huge battles even in 1v1 games. Turbo features which i have not use much as i prefer the classical gameplay can make for intense fast battles and more engaging stalemate periods. The new ai play smarter somewhat and multible ai options make it good for multible play styles. All of the new nations i have played so far are astonishingly balanced and fit right in.

The bad:
Elephants everywhere if you play full-tech like i personally do. Lag but that is to be expected though out of battle the game runs extremely well the only mayor issue for me being corpses instead of living units idk why. Games are a lot shorter which is not a true negative but i do miss old school games that went up to 30 hours and spanned weeks of play. Cloud storage for game saves might get frustrating but i do not fully understand if its a backup or a main way of saving. Map sizes feel a lot smaller or it might just be faster units. The standard ai is overly agressive and the surplus of relics fules the endless high tier unit spam. Defensive ai(CD) dose not wall up as good as it used to in the 1999. version which i do sorely miss. 

I do love this game both me and my dad which are long time original players are well supprised and we both love our time ingame so far. I am yet to finish a campaign or play multiplayer but neither of us ever did do either. Game is still as brilliantly balanced and unique among rts games as it ever was if not more so and i will happily be playing it for 10 years more and longer.

This game is a masterpiece. I haven't played any of the other Age of Empires games, but if they're all just as good as this one, then I would definitely give them a try. The RTS gameplay mechanics work amazingly well with both single player and online play. The interface is a bit overwhelming at first, but after the tutorial, it becomes pretty easy to understand. All the hotkeys are very consistent and can make simple actions SO much easier. All the civilizations seem to balance each other out from my experience, and the many customization options allow for complete balancing where all nations have the same upgrades regardless.

My only issue with this game is the default game speed. However, that problem is easily fixed by changing the game speed in the settings, so it's not that big of a deal. Overall, fantastic game, and I am glad to see this franchise doing so well.

"Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition" revitalizes the classic real-time strategy (RTS) game, enhancing it for a new generation while staying true to what made the original beloved. Developed by Forgotten Empires and published by Xbox Game Studios, this definitive edition offers improved graphics, a re-orchestrated soundtrack, new content, and quality-of-life improvements, making it the ultimate version of a timeless strategy game. This review assesses "Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition" based on its gameplay mechanics, content richness, graphical and audio upgrades, multiplayer experience, and overall value to both newcomers and veterans of the franchise.

Gameplay Mechanics
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
The core gameplay of "Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition" remains as engaging as ever, requiring players to gather resources, build towns, raise armies, and conquer enemies. The game's mechanics are a testament to the enduring appeal of the RTS genre, offering a balance between economic management, technological advancement, and tactical combat. Quality-of-life improvements, such as enhanced pathfinding, unit queuing, and an improved UI, streamline the experience without sacrificing depth, making the game accessible to new players while retaining the complexity veterans appreciate.

Content Richness
Rating: 10/10 - Masterpiece
This definitive edition is packed with content, featuring all previously released expansions and introducing new campaigns and civilizations. With over 35 civilizations to play and numerous campaigns, each with its own historical storyline, the game boasts an impressive amount of replayability. New content, like "The Last Khans" expansion, adds even more depth to the game's already vast library, ensuring that players have countless hours of gameplay ahead of them.

Graphical and Audio Upgrades
Rating: 8/10 - Good
"Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition" receives a significant graphical overhaul, with enhanced textures, lighting, and water effects that bring the medieval world to life. The 4K support and redesigned UI offer a modernized visual experience while preserving the game's iconic aesthetic. The re-orchestrated soundtrack and improved sound effects breathe new life into the auditory experience, although some purists may prefer the original compositions. While the graphics are not cutting-edge compared to contemporary RTS games, they represent a faithful and beautiful update to the original.

Multiplayer Experience
Rating: 8/10 - Good
The multiplayer component of "Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition" is robust, featuring cross-play support, a new matchmaking system, and dedicated servers for a smoother online experience. The community is active, catering to both competitive players and those looking for casual fun. While the matchmaking system is a welcome addition, some players may experience occasional connectivity issues or imbalances in player skill levels. Despite these minor setbacks, the multiplayer experience is a highlight, offering endless challenges against players worldwide.

Overall Value
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
"Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition" offers exceptional value, combining classic gameplay with substantial new content and improvements. It serves both as a nostalgic trip for long-time fans and an accessible entry point for newcomers. The game's price point is reasonable, considering the amount of content and the level of polish applied to this classic title.

Overall Summary and Score
"Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition" is a triumphant update to one of the most beloved RTS games of all time. It successfully modernizes the classic for today's audience without losing the essence that made the original so captivating. With its rich content, improved visuals and audio, and engaging multiplayer, this definitive edition is a must-have for strategy enthusiasts.

Highly Recommended for both RTS veterans and newcomers. Whether you're reliving your cherished memories or discovering the game for the first time, "Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition" offers a comprehensive and enriching strategy experience that stands the test of time.

Update: With the addition of Lords of the West, it is an amazing expansion. I have always wanted an Edward Longshanks campaign given that he is your enemy in the tutorial campaign. After literal decades it finally happened and it's an amazing campaign!!! Balance changes for multiplayer are being worked for the Burgundians and Sicilians, but overall the expansion is worth the money if you love this franchise or if you just want to add two solid factions to your mix.

Update: Dynasties of India was added, all 3 campaigns were extremely fun and presented some of their own challenges. I can say as of writing that I have completed every single campaign that the game has to offer and quite a few of them I'd play again. Highly recommend all the DLCs, if you don't have the money for it upfront just wait for a sale. They are all worth the full asking price though. 

Update: Completed the Return of Rome campaign. I believe it is well worth the money despite some disliking because it is basically an excuse to port over AoE1DE. You basically get both games rolled into the same, but it does add 3 new campaigns with the AoE2 storytelling style and after beating the original AoE1 campaigns again you realize just how much better AoE2's take on storytelling is. With the completion of this DLC, I have completed all DLC currently available as of 01/31/2024. Every DLC outside of the cosmetic DLC is very worth it imo, it adds hours upon hours of campaign gameplay and new civs/refreshes.

This game continues to receive love and support from the developers and they do listen to community input. Of any RTS I have ever played it is absolutely insane how well balanced each of the civilizations are with just how many there are. Some are stronger against certain civs than others, but player skill is the biggest defining factor in whether or not you will lose your matches. There really aren't any civs that "hard" counter another civ, they can all be played and as long as you understand your civs strengths and weaknesses it truly does come down to player skill. This game is and will continue to be a staple in the RTS genre of what every RTS game should aspire to be like. In my opinion there is no other RTS game that even comes close to the overall experience AoE2 gives you both in the single player aspect and multiplayer. The community is also pretty awesome as well!

DLC ranking imho (best to worst):
Lords of the West
Dynasties of India
Dawn of the Dukes
The Mountain Royals
Return of Rome

Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition is an absolute beast of a game that kicks you right in the feels with a nostalgia uppercut. This isn't just a remaster; it's a nostalgia-packed time machine that catapults you back to the days when MSN gaming zone was the battleground of kings!

If you were a fan of the original Age of Empires II, prepare to have your mind blown and your inner warrior unleashed. The Definitive Edition doesn't just polish the graphics; it's like taking your favorite medieval battle simulator and injecting it with a hefty dose of steroids. The graphics are sharper than a knight's sword, and the attention to detail is so meticulous it's almost obsessive ‚Äì and I love it.

But let's talk about the nostalgia ‚Äì it's like a warm, comforting hug from an old friend who just happens to be wielding a trebuchet. The soundtrack, oh, the glorious soundtrack! Every familiar note sends shivers down your spine as memories of epic skirmishes and castle sieges flood back. It's not just a game; it's a journey back to the good old days when the lobby of MSN gaming zone was our sacred arena, and alliances were forged or shattered with a single click.

The gameplay is as intense as ever, and the addition of new civilizations and campaigns is like a banquet for strategy enthusiasts. The balance is so finely tuned that you can almost taste the blood, sweat, and tears that went into making this masterpiece. Again, it's not just a game; it's a battleground where you'll forge alliances, betray friends, and send waves of armies to crush your enemies.

The multiplayer experience is a thing of beauty. It's not just about skill; it's about cunning, strategy, and the satisfaction of outsmarting your opponents. The thrill of a well-executed rush or the sweet taste of revenge as you wipe out an enemy's economy ‚Äì it's pure gaming ecstasy. And of course there's ELO hell, but that's another matter.

In conclusion, Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition isn't just a trip down memory lane; it's a full-blown warpath of nostalgia. It's aggressive in its assault on your emotions, dragging you back to the glory days of gaming. It's not for the faint-hearted ‚Äì it's for those who crave the rush of a perfectly executed boom or the sweet taste of victory after an epic comeback. Get ready to relive the old glory days, because Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition is here to conquer your heart all over again. Awww yeaaahhhh. Wololooooo

Age of Empires II is a legendary game that has become a classic over time in the realm of strategy games. Developed by Ensemble Studios and published by Microsoft, this game allows players to lead epic wars with historical civilizations. Here are some key features of this game:

Graphics and Art Design:
Despite being released in 1999, Age of Empires II boasts graphics and art design beyond the standards of its time. The detailed maps, structures, and units in the game make players feel the unique characteristics of each civilization. Despite its 2D graphics, the aesthetic quality of the game is still noteworthy.

Various Civilizations and Strategic Diversity:
Age of Empires II represents different civilizations from world history. Each civilization has its own units, buildings, and advantages. This provides players with strategic diversity, ensuring that each game offers a different experience.

Legendary Music and Sound Effects:
The game's music immerses players in a historical atmosphere, while the sound effects during battles enhance the intensity of the conflicts. Age of Empires II's music is still praised by many players today.

Campaign Mode and Storytelling:
Age of Empires II features carefully crafted campaigns, each focusing on significant events and leaders throughout history. These campaigns offer players an engaging storytelling experience, bringing together both strategy and history enthusiasts.

Multiplayer and Competitive Play:
The multiplayer mode allows players to compete against each other worldwide. This provides an opportunity for players to test and improve their strategic skills against others.

Conclusion:
Age of Empires II is a classic masterpiece among strategy games. With its rich historical atmosphere, diverse civilizations, and deep strategic gameplay, it provides players with an unforgettable experience. This game, standing the test of time, continues to be an appealing and enjoyable choice for strategy enthusiasts.

This game has something to offer for all types of players.

You like easy games to chill and relax with? Just set the AI difficulty to lowest, or even make everyone allies. Go at your own pace and play this game like a city builder. 

You want to make your own fun? The Scenario builder lets you design your own maps and create own missions 

You looking to play through a game with a story? There's plenty of historical campaigns with engaging stories and challenging scenarios to play through.

You seeking a competitive online multiplayer game? The online ranked mode puts you head to head on the ranked ladder against players around the world. Wherever you end up on the ladder, the Elo rating system guarantees you will be facing someone of similar skill and have a balanced and evenly matched game. 

This game was a masterpiece 20 years ago, and is every bit as good now as it was then. A true timeless classic, remastered perfectly - Not too much added to take away from the nostalgia, yet just the right amount of graphical improvements and quality of life changes to make it enjoyable in modern times

I've probably played several thousand hours in AoE II in one way or another.  I have the original disc from when I was a kid, which is where most of my playtime comes from because it was my only PC game for the longest time.  Plus HD edition.  Now AoE II DE.  

This game is comfort food.  Old reliable.  I know that whenever I boot up this game, I'm going to learn something, or have fun, or both!  It has its quirks, but don't we all?  To see that this game is as expansive as it is now is a dream for eight year old me, who would try to build crossbows out of pencils, or trebuchets out of sticks and rocks.

Gosh, I love this game.

Positives: It is intuitive, meaning that the learning curve is not all that steep.
                It has layers of depth, and I can play the game five times, and it will never be precisely the same.
                It requires strategy, speed, and a need to take a few chances (saves are needful)

Negatives: The interface can be a bit "clunky" at times. It is a game designed around mouse clicks.
                  There are times that the computer players seem to start with an unfair advantage, either in 
                       resources or in personnel.
                   
Conclusion: This is an old game that has stood the test of time. The graphics are decent, and the gameplay challenging enough to keep me coming back for more (once or twice every decade). Good job, Microsoft!

Or you're playing against a premade stack that goes for the boring meta strat.

Plus doesn't seem to be just me, i'm experiencing an even higher number of leavers or non-loading players in ranked matches... i'd guess more than half my games are won/lost that way or never even happen.

____________________________________________

TLDR: The game has the potential to be very enjoyable and is nostalgic bliss but also still plagued with lots of bugs and connection issues in the current patch. Come back to this later once it's more stable (again?).

Enjoyed the game when i picked it back up last year, mostly due to childhood nostalgia and having been starved of a good RTS for a long time.

At the moment it's a bit of a love hate relationship for me. Why?

The unit movement/behaviour feels quite dated and clunky to me which sometimes can lead to the game overall feeling more like I'm wrestling the pathfinding and inputs than conveying orders and commanding a civilization.
On the other hand IF I get into a game which is reasonably well balanced on a map I enjoy it can be great fun... even if it's a bit stressful during the late-game with so much going on, especially when playing 3v3/4v4 without coms lol.

In the end what makes me not recommend the game at this point is the amount of bugs I'm experiencing lately. I highlighted the "if" earlier because quite often I don't even get into the game but instead get booted to the main menu with an "unexpected error" message. Which leads to increasing multiplayer timebans because the engine judges the crash as you abandoning a matchmaking game. Great.
On top of that the game creation process just decides to fuck up sometimes. For example scrambling civs in my team - not random civs but players getting matched the wrong civs within the team. E.g I pick Spanish and get Huns while my teammate picked Huns and got Spanish.
I even ended up in a 2v4 ranked match where i had queued for 3v3 and we were three players on our team in the lobby. But once we hit loading screen one of our teammates was put into the opponent team.
And even if i get into a game and all the settings are indeed correct, noone is lagging heavily and teams are somewhat balanced there's still a good chance that AoE2 decides to completely hardlock my PC. Like sound keeps playing but everything else stops responing to any kind of input. Literally no other game i have installed does that. From competitive multiplayer games to single player adventures. And it's not because so much is going on and my PC runs out of juice, it can happen during dark age witch 2 players on a tiny map.

Last but not least it's quite irritating to me that I only get a single map ban when queuing for team games, but three for solo ladder. With the map pool being relatively deep at least two bans for team ladder would be such a quality of life improvement... I just don't enjoy playing what feels like half my games on either Arena or Black Forest.

Final verdict - there's a reason the game is still popular this long after its initial release and why so many of us remember the childhood days fondly where we noobed around against the AI or had LAN nights with aoe and wc3. But in its current state for the amount of development time there could have been I won't recommend it. There are enough other games to enjoy first, come back to this later when it gets more stable.

This game cannot be evaluated by measured by any rating scale. The game itself sets the standard for games like these!
I've played this game since my childhood - long before the HD or now the DE Edition and even before it was on Steam. If I would write down everything I know and value about this game, this textbox would cover the whole review area. So I'll keep it to some personal opinions about this game, rather than a full explanation of the game's details.
To me, there isn't any better strategy game with such an amount of possibilities. No game is alike the game before and you always discover something new. Whether you play alone or with friends - it's always fun. 
And never have I experienced a game with such a friendly and long lasting fanbase, that achieves two remakes, and the steady addition of new content over decades.
Also, aside from the gameplay itself, for the historian I became, this game has always offered so much to discover in terms of historical events and diverse cultures.
I'm thankful for that the game has accompanied me for so long in my life and shaped who I become and that it also will in the future!

If you weren't playing real-time strategy games back in the mid-late 1990's, I cannot hold it against you for not being familiar with Microsoft's premier RTS franchise Age of Empires.  However, going into 2020 Age of Empires made has made a fierce comeback into mainstream gaming when the franchise pinnacle stormed onto XBOX and Game Pass - Ladies & Gentlemen, that is THIS GAME!
Age of Empires II: Age of Kings originally launched on Windows 98 (for most people, otherwise Windows 2000), followed by it's expansion AoE2: Age of Conquerors introducing The American tribes to West vs East Eurasian Medieval slugfest.  I was one of those was introduced to AoE when buying AoE2 Gold Edition (Base + Expansion).  The original campaigns were alright, but I honestly found the real meat of Age of Empires lie in the skirmish and multiplayer action.  Age of Empires II is set in the medieval period and players progress across four R&D stages (as with any AoE game).  Players build up their bases, managing their population pool between villagers, military and support units to eventually eliminating opponents.  In addition to the traditional conquest skirmish match, you have additional modes with their own strategies.
Between the original and current resurgent releases, Age of Empires II has maintained a strong player and modding community.  AoE2 has remained the preferred entry for Age of Empires' competitive scene - Competitive AoE sounds a lot like the "Rugby" of RTS with Empire Wars (short form action-heavy format) and traditional full-length games both having their respective E-Sports presence.
AoE2HD got peoples' attention on Steam, Definitive Edition debuted the franchise on XBOX made became a household name for Game Pass users.  If you're wondering how this game fairs on a gamepad...  Surprisingly well, actually - Gamepad vs Keyboard/Mouse is like comparing Automatic vs Manual: Each have their strengths and weakness, but ultimately come down to personal preferences given how intuitively AoE plays on an XBOX controller.  If you prefer automation, you're going to warm very quickly to controller.  Purists however will naturally consider that blasphemy and play as they always have.  Any which way you play, AoE2 Definitive has Cross-Platform multiplayer for players new and old to enjoy!

Would I recommend Age of Empires II Definitive Edition?

If you consider yourself a self-respecting real-time strategy connoisseur...  Absolutely!
With the William Wallace campaign newcomers will have concise set of tutorials to give a solid introduction to the basics of AoE and a skill foundation to build upon.

I've had thousands of games and thousands of hours of gameplay on this laptop. Their October/November 2023 update made it completely unplayable. A game that I'd previously been able to play without issue now crashes my computer every single time I attempt to play it. Now it doesn't last more than 10 seconds on the main menu before it crashes not just the game, but my entire computer.

I've tried:
uninstalling and reinstalling the game
Disabling overlays
Disabling all mods
reducing fps and graphic quality
Running game as administrator
Disconnecting internet and starting game offline
Increase virtual memory size to 32GB
Updating windows drivers
Updating Nvidia drivers
Disabling any antivirus programs before running the game
Opening the game in windowed mode

Nothing works. This is by far the most amount of effort I have put into getting a game to work again. No other games have ever been this troublesome to run. And the sad thing is it USED to work just fine on this same machine. So it's not a hardware issue.

Here's the machine specs:
Machine is a Razer Blade laptop
Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-7700HQ CPU @ 2.80GHz   2.80 GHz
16GB RAM
NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 (14GB total memory, 6GB VRAM)
Windows 10 Home (64-bit operating system, x64-based processor)
DirectX 12 (DirectDraw enabled, Direct3D enabled, AGP texture accel enabled)

IMO, no longer worth the risk of purchasing only to find out that it doesn't work on your machine.

Amazing RTS!!! Top tier in the genre.

While it's impressive seeing AOE2 maintained and new DLCs being released and a live scene, the game actually needs to be in a playable state.

A combination of 90% of games desyncing between my wife and i in the same house on the same network, unit pathing getting worse every patch, and decisions changing that make no sense, the game gets more and more frustrating to continue playing. Who in the world decided that the new default top priority target for trebuchets needed to be farms? We have a big rock to throw and do damage to an enemy civilisation. How best to use our rock? Throw it into that big open field with no one in it, that'll show em.

Grumping aside, you can see the decisions are not being thought through. I bought a 2000$ PC to play a 1997 game.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Playing Age of Empires II with friends can be great fun. Agree on some rules for maximum fun for everyone (or don't), and just have at it. AoE2 is also a very nostalgic game with great visual- and mechanical design, that I certainly think can offer at least some entertainment.

However, going into online multiplayer, and even playing against the AI, can quickly get ridiculous. To me, Age of Empires II feels designed to be a rather demanding game. Being competitive, having good APM, and being great at hyper-efficiency and multi-tasking, all seem required here. I'm a bit more of a casual player, and thus I often feel like I stand little chance, even against the AI.

Speaking of AI, the differences between difficulties are insane. Play on Easiest or Standard, and the AI barely does anything. At most, all it does against me is send a few infantry/archers every couple minutes, with some occasional rams if they're feeling spicy. However, anything beyond Standard suddenly has this huge difficulty spike that expects you to be great at the game.

Playing against Moderate, I often get destroyed. Whereas the AI was a pushover before, now they're juggling multiple things at once: bringing villagers to repair their 10+ siege weapons mid-combat, have monks dip in and out of combat to convert my units, dodging siege projectiles with their units, and more... And all that's just on Moderate! I can't imagine the insanity of what Hard, Hardest and Extreme would be like. There just seems to be many steps missing in-between difficulties.

On top of all that, this game has [b]horrendous[/b] pathing. For example, when giving a group of units an attack/move order, they'll often take a longer and nonsensical route to avoid a single tree or something. Or they'll zigzag and slow down and rotate around eachother just for a single straggler to get back into their precious formation. There's more to this, but let's just say that you're often left fighting your own units as much as you're fighting the enemy.

While Age of Empires can admittedly be an enjoyable game in certain aspects, I still recommend you only play it if you're very competent and competitive at strategy games like these, or if you plan to play primarily with friends. I'll probably keep playing the game every now and then to see how far I'll get, but I certainly would've liked this game a lot more if it had been more welcoming.

GOAT GAME

I have been playing on and off this game for about 20 years with previous versions included (HD/AoC disk version).

[h3]Let's start with the positives:[/h3]
[list]
[*]The game balance is about at its best it has ever been civilization wise.
[*]There are updates being released that address balance
[*]Many Quality of Life features that are exclusive to DE - like the queue of farms (from AoC) expanded to "auto farm reseed"
[*]There is a queue system for ranked play
[*]New textures & 4k textures available
[*]New campaigns. Although most of them are behind separate DLCs, the content is there
[/list]

[h3]Now to the negatives[/h3]
[list]
[*]Although Public Update Preview (PUP) is usually available before a new patch, it's not uncommon for game breaking bugs to make it past the phase. This includes games crashing as well as "infinite relic multiplication"
[*]Pathing. One of the core systems to an RTS game, updates claiming "pathing improvements" or "fixes" usually made it worse.
[/list]

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
You, the person reading this, is probably asking right now: Why is the review negative with the positives list being so much longer?
In one word: pathing.
In longer explanation:
As I have mentioned I've been playing the game on and off for about 20 years. And I want to cry now that I uninstalled the game since it is one of the games I love. 
The game breaking bugs usually got patched quickly after being found. I could see past some of the non-trivial ones. Though, it still happened more often than not, it is not the end of the world as it got fixed and I could continue playing the game.
The point when it started to go downhill is when pathing, a core system, was started being altered. It was slowly getting worse, occasionally getting better. However the current state is very bad. 
If you're interested how bad, take a look at the following video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=apKc3Q1xQyE
In game it feels like units are not listening to the command. Units will shuffle around instead of walking, villagers randomly stop and walking 8 tiles around the building rather than going around the building from the other side which is about 3 tiles.

[h3]Do I recommend this game?[/h3]
If you want to play only single player and you don't play multiplayer, possibly. You might not notice the pathing. Still, be warned
For anyone wanting to play multiplayer/ranked games: Big No. Units seemingly not listening to commands should be an immediate turn off.
One of the greatest RTS games of all time. Tons of campaign levels and tons of single and multiplayer content.

The game is a gem for the Strategy/City Building categories. Of course I recommend it! 
Is quite easy and for all ages. Although you may spend quite a bit of time before you manage to win, it is quite fun and not tiring at all. The admins pays attention to the comments and reports of the players and tries to solve every problem that exists in the game. 

The DLC market needs some attention. Because DLC Return of Rome is completely different from simple AoE2 Definitive Edition. ( I hadn't read it so I just bought it and found difficulties in it. )
(Some basic things you should know is that it doesn't have Relics to automatically get money like in AoE2 Definitive Edition with monks. It also doesn't have a trap farming option if you want to collect food by Sea. It has other tricks separately, so before you buy any DLC check out video someone who has already played it. (Personally I didn't like Return of Rome because it doesn't suit me playfully)
But that doesn't matter at all. The DLC is purely our choice if we want to buy it.

AOE II DE is surprisingly fresh and still quite enjoyable even after all this time. With the Rise of Rome DLC, you don't need AOE I and, let's face it, AOE III is not as good (that home cities idea was a mistake). I will even state that I have no urgent desire to invest in AOE IV, especially since I have all the major DLC for AOE II DE. The developers are aware of the lasting appeal of this version; witness the recent release of "The Mountain Royals."

Ok, so my opinion has changed significantly since it's first release. At first I was like OMG another 1? puhhhleezzee. The HD version is good enough, I'll pass....

But now I actually do recommend this game. I have upgraded my rig since then and I can finally play it without the fps drop. Even with a high end rig if you play a map with max players and tons of characters are running around everywhere carelessly, then still expect to see a fps drop. I believe it's just how the game is coded. I don't think they will ever fix that problem unless they re-code from the ground up.

With that issue out of the way, the game play and campaigns are all still the same, but with a little bit more added, and that's not including DLC campaigns. 

The resolution and graphics are beautiful to glance at on a 4K screen. Hard to believe I ran this on windows 98 back in the day at 1024x768. My how times have changed. Even though they feel the same.

The DE version is only for Steam on modern PC's, do not run this on your 10 year old rig. Just play the HD version instead. You'll understand why. But if your PC doesn't suck then yea, totally pick this up It's fun and worth every cent when it's on sale.

This is the best RTS game, I would stretch to general game on the whole of steam, maybe ever created. This game has kept me interested for over 6k+ hours including the HD edition, and I still feel like I could play it for the rest of my life. No matter what, get this game. For a relatively historically accurate PVP-based RTS game, it absolutely excels. 25 years after it was created originally, AoE2 is still going strong, and the community all feels the same way about this game. In over 10 years of playing this, I have never met a single hacker, and only 3 toxic players.

The map editor I have probably spent over 1000h on, you can pretty much edit the game in any way you wish. The UI in the editor and across the whole game is easy to navigate, tooltips are shown for newer players and everything is specified clearly.

I would again, repeat my point on the community. I have almost never had a bad time playing this game, thanks to all the wonderful community members.

I have gotten 5 friends to get this game, and 3 have loved it and the other two haven't really tried it enough to know yet. This game is absolutely timeless. Scroll up right now, and download the game. This game is educational, fun, strategic, and will be absolutely playable in 5 years time. I would buy it for 5x the price and it would still be worth my money.

I cannot emphasise with words how worth it this game is. Different to every other game on the market.

I don‚Äôt get why this game is hyped so much. I loved AoK as a kid and after 30 minutes of playing the so-called ‚ÄúDefinitive Edition‚Äù, I‚Äôm already disappointed.

When you first start the game you immediately find out that everything your cursor touches is read out. That‚Äôs a great accessibility feature. What‚Äôs not great is that the voice is unbearably robotic and fails to even pronounce the game‚Äôs title correctly. It also makes awkward pauses while reading. I wonder if this is really useful to visually impaired players.

What‚Äôs bad about this is: How do you turn it off? The toggles are not clearly labeled, so I had to google to find them. Side note: There are three toggles, one controls the voiceover in the menu, one ingame and the third I forgot. Only the one for the menu is enabled by default. What‚Äôs the point of that? Once you‚Äôre in your first game, accessibility is toggled of by default.

I launched the tutorial to see if anything meaningful changed. The visuals did, but not much more. Oh, and the beautiful Scottish voice from the William Wallace campaign got replaced by someone who didn‚Äôt even try to sound Scottish. What a shame!

Playing the first ‚Äúhow to get good‚Äù campaign (which I find a nice addition), I tried to change the hotkeys, since I like to scroll using WASD, which isn‚Äôt possible by default. Guess what? There as a whole menu for changing the hotkeys, which is [url="https://forums.ageofempires.com/t/changing-hotkey-defaults-does-not-work-stuck-in-classic-hotkeys-and-cant-switch-to-definitive-hotkeys/184738/35"]broken at least since January 2021[/url]! This is so infuriating. You made the effort to make the game accessible to visually impaired gamers, but fail to make hotkeys work for 3 years‚Åâ

Further into the campaign I noticed that clicking buttons doesn‚Äôt work about half the time. No, I‚Äôm not too dumb to read my resource stocks. I have more than 50 food, enough housing, click the button to create a pawn, and nothing happens. Only after I move the cursor, I can click it. This occurs so often that I wonder if the devs even played their game once during ‚Äòtesting‚Äô.

While aiming for gold in the resource gathering challenge, I repeatedly found that pawns would stand idly for a few seconds before remembering that they‚Äôre shepherds and killing the next sheep. That‚Äôs infuriating when you‚Äôre always a few seconds short of obtaining the gold medal. I thought with 2023 technology fetching the next task for a pawn should be instant, but well‚Ä¶

I still have my old copy of AoK, but it doesn‚Äôt work on new Windows versions because Microsoft decided not to bundle a codec the game needs. With a game this shitty (that used to be great), I really wonder what Microsoft‚Äôs cut in the sales is.

I got the game for ‚Ç¨5, and I‚Äôm still pondering whether I should return it.

Never played so many hours on 1 game, 450 at time of review. I've loved strategy since the very originals like C&C, Dune, Strategic Commander and perhaps only the latter comes close to the depth of AoE2. There's a reason so many people have played it for so long and continue doing so. It's just unbelievable. Despite all my hours, I only play to a fairly mediocre level and find doing all the campaigns on Hard is taking me a while (no point in doing on any other mode!)

Simply put, there's as much depth as you want, but it's still super enjoyable even if you don't learn every specific upgrade and counter attack unit in detail.

Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition is a fantastic remaster of a classic real-time strategy game. The game features stunning 4K graphics, a fully-remastered soundtrack, and a wealth of new content, including new civilizations, units, and technologies.

PROS
‚Ä¢ Nice 4K graphics
‚Ä¢ Fully-remastered soundtrack
‚Ä¢ New civilizations, units, and technologies
‚Ä¢ 20+ years of content with all the expansions
‚Ä¢ Great for both single-player and multiplayer
‚Ä¢ New AI

CONS
‚Ä¢ Some minor balance issues
‚Ä¢ AI can be a bit too easy at times (or too hard)

OVERALL
Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition is a must-have for any fan of real-time strategy games. The game is a faithful recreation of the classic, with all the bells and whistles that modern gamers expect. Whether you're a longtime fan of the series or a newcomer, Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition is a great way to experience one of the best real-time strategy games of all time.

MY PERSONAL EXPERIENCE
As someone who played the original Age of Empires II in 1999, I was excited to see how the Definitive Edition would turn out. I was not disappointed. The game looks and sounds amazing, and the new content is a welcome addition. I've had a lot of fun playing the game both solo and multiplayer.

RECOMMENDATION
If you're a fan of real-time strategy games, I highly recommend Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition. It's a great way to experience a classic game with nice graphics and gameplay.

Strategy starts to begin to matter and make a difference more in this sequel of the Age of Empires series. In AOE 2, your choice on build, town, villagers, upgrades, and units make a very significant impact on how your game will progress. Winning or losing will depend solely on you and your opponent even if you have a better economy and larger army. Massing as a strategy does not work in this game. 

This game truly embodies the core of what makes AOE series great and probably one of the most tactical RTS games out there. The difference between players is large depending on who is playing and the skill ceiling is very high. Unlike most RTS games, microing is far more hectic and unorthodox. The difference in the skill of players is truly seen in this game, if this was a really popular competitive esport today, I have no doubt it would be one of the most enjoyable to watch. 

Even for single player campaigns, the slide show cinematics and art work although minimal really encapsulate each of the nations and is also historically accurate as you play each of the main characters. You get to learn about the history of various civilizations while playing as the heros of them from every nation and continent around the world in a game. Even if you aren't a fan of RTS or playing competitively/multiplayer, this is well worth your dollar just to play for the story.

It certainly runs better than the HD (2013) version, and is probably the best way to play age of empires 2 currently. If you are looking for the old classic experience however, you will need to download userpatches for the old age of kings/conquerors cd versions.

The game however is still riddled with issues that never seem to get fixed and if they do, they return or worsen after a patch or two.

- Pathfinding
- Odd behavior from units that I've never seen before in other versions of the game
- Unsolicited ahistorical civ inclusions to sell increasingly overpriced DLCs with waning quality of campaigns
- Playing Ludikris sized maps still cause the game to freeze up and stutter occasionally
- FOMO "balance" patches which does nothing to fix core issues with the game or overpowered civs included beyond the classic experience, but only serve to upset the meta for little to no payoff in the end
- No steamworkshop which means having to login to a microsoft account, and is infinitely more frustrating to navigate and search for specific mod/map content.

Is the definitive edition a direct upgrade over previous versions? I would describe it as more of a sidegrade than anything. Make no mistake this is not the classic experience of age of empires, but a modern remake with all the bells and whistles of a newer engine and QoL improvements. Along with the improvements come the negative sides of being a modern remake, the live service, the seasonal updates (gotta have those player interaction metrics) and the massive creep of scope to monetize DLC.
A great polish to a great title. The game overflows with both singleplayer and multiplayer content and is continuously balanced by the developers. The go-to game for us RTS lovers!

In terms of strategy games, Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition is a triumph. With a perfect 5/5 for its amazing updated graphics and historical authenticity, the game's fundamental principles are still legendary, albeit with a few minor tweaks like a better UI and queue system. The campaigns, which combine interesting tasks with historical narration, receive a commendable 4.8/5. With a perfect 5/5, multiplayer is excellent and offers a variety of game options and a lively community. Constant developer support (rated 5/5) guarantees a constantly improving experience. This timeless masterwork captivates both veterans and beginners with a spectacular 4.9/5 ending, promising another year of epic conquests and alliances.

Paid: 14.99GBP

PROs
+ great long term value and replayability
+ nice to see that this oldie got its proper remaster
+ fun campaigns
+ great music
+ lots of civs
+ micro transactions are great for investors, and you have the choice not to buy
+ some nice automations like farm auto re-seed and 1st scout auto scouting
+ lots of mods
+ you aren't forced to play multiplayer, and if you do, please play with 3 friends, or you'll lose interest as you lost the first 50+ games which can get very frustrating
+ not a hectic as StarCraft
+ lovely rock, paper, scissor mechanics
+ lots of people are still playing this game
+ a lot less toxic community than League of Legends, CoD

CONs
- performance poor on i5-8350U with Intel HD 620 iGPU (22FPS)
- graphics cannot be dialled down low enough
- if 1 player lags, everyone's game experience suffers as everyone's game slows to the weakest player's experience
- no improvement to unit path finding which is still atrocious 24 years after OG AoE2's release
- zoom out contents directly linked to monitor resolution: 2.5k on 27" or 4k on 32" recommended
- English voice acting is worse than OG AoE2, and everyone sounds generically American without any effort of putting on an accent
- Ranged units don't have a melee attack like in Battle Realms or Metal Fatigue (really underrated)
- the game snowballs very quickly as many inefficiencies add up later on

Issue with multiplayer:
- 20% of matches are smurfs ruining everyone's experience
- waiting to find 4v4 matches takes 10-15min
- you are forced to play maps you don't like
- you can only ban 4 cards on 4v4, but we only want to play Black Forest, Amazon Tunnel and Arena...
- you need to commit to at least 45min time investment per game incl. waiting time
- can be really stressful when you haven't played in a many months, and you need to constantly multi task

It's just a very well made game, I highly recommend it. Tons of quality-of-life features that you rarely see in other games, it's satisfying, it runs well (unless your opponent in multiplayer is producing lag). It allows for a lot of creativity in your approach. There are also tons of campaigns that take a long time to play through, in the good sense.

There are issues with the game (currently, unit pathing is in a pretty bad state), but it still receives active updates and the issues are tolerable, unlike in many other games. 

Learning to play well requires a lot of practice, but you can just play single player, with friends, or simply let the ranked matchmaker place you in the lower brackets. Low-skill ranked is probably more fun anyway. Playing skirmish games against the AI is fine, but the AI gets rather predictable.

You don't need any of the DLCs to have a full experience. The DLCs add new campaigns and new civilizations (with the exception of "Return of Rome", which adds some other things as well, but that's not that relevant). There are plenty of civilizations in the base game to play as, so I would recommend getting a feel for the game and then deciding which of the DLC civilizations you're interested in.

[b]Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition revitalizes the classic RTS game, offering a blend of nostalgia and modern enhancements that appeal to both die-hard fans and newcomers alike.

[i]Pros:
Classic Revival: This edition breathes new life into the beloved Age of Empires II, preserving its essence while introducing updated graphics and sound, bringing back the joy of the original game.
Extensive Content: With over 35 civilizations, a plethora of campaigns, and a variety of game modes, the Definitive Edition presents a vast amount of content, ensuring countless hours of strategic gameplay.
Enhanced Visuals and Audio: The improved graphics and remastered soundtracks give the game a fresh, polished feel while retaining the nostalgic charm of the original.
Support and Updates: The developers continue to support the game with regular updates, addressing issues and adding new content, showcasing a commitment to keeping the community engaged.

Cons:
Learning Curve: For newcomers to the RTS genre or those unfamiliar with the original game, the learning curve might be a bit steep due to the game's depth and complexity.
Pathfinding Issues: Occasionally, units may exhibit pathfinding quirks, leading to instances of inefficient movement or getting stuck in certain situations.[/i]

So this concludes that Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition successfully bridges the gap between past and present, offering a robust RTS experience with its wealth of content, updated visuals, and ongoing support. While it may pose a challenge for newcomers, its classic gameplay and enduring appeal make it a must-have for strategy enthusiasts and fans of the series.[/b]

I am downgrading from a 4/10 to a 2/10 now to a 1/10. I just played a game as I try to come back to this game periodically to see if they have improved it. I created 3 horse units in the beginning of the game, I was able to get into the area where they were chopping wood, I put my units onto aggressive attack stance and then patrolled the area so they would attack and instead they just stood there and died. This game is such a joke. 

I am downgrading to a 1/10 because of how slow this game is. The villagers walk exceedingly slow and the trees in the game are so far away. It can take up to 12 minutes to 15 minutes to even get units built and everything is just so slow. 

The economy in this game is also very slow. It cost a lot of money to upgrade your economy and if you decide to go with melee units you will have a tremendously hard time fighting off arrows as well as upgrading your economy and the units themselves as there are not enough food options in the beginning of the game.

This game is basically play one or two styles if you want to be competitive and takes away all the fun of trying something to out smart somebody. It just doesn't exist in this game. 

I periodically come back to this game because i've been playing it for so long to see if it gets improved. 

On 12/13/23 I tried to play the new mini game which I thought was a fantastic addition to this game, however, disappointing. 

When you are controlling a group of units in this game (in general not just mini game) instead of clicking for them to run right or left they will regroup and get stuck inside the enemy units. Which gets them killed. In the actual game itself this is already absurdly annoying and in this particular mini game the entire point is to keep the units alive and protect the wonder. A really fun idea and i am thoroughly surprised they added this into the game however the controls of this game again have made it more annoying to play than fun.

A timeless classic and a true masterpiece of RTS gaming. 
If you're already into RTS' then this is a no-brainer, but if your're new to the scene then a word of caution because it can be a little overwhelming at first, but if you muster through the first few hours of confusion and frustration, you'll soon see why this is such a beloved genre. Stick with it and you'll have some of the most fun and gratifying moments in gaming.

The game has a lot to offer, for both single-player lovers with it's extensive campaigns, which can also be played in Co-Op, and for those who are more into multiplayer with both a competitive mode and casual lobbies. Not to mention the endless amount of custom maps, modes and mods on offer from the community in the Steam Workshop.

If you already own the AoK or HD (2013) version, I would still highly recommend this, as it has all of the original DLC included, not to mention the beautiful graphics and art. And the QoL changes cannot be understated because it really does feel like a fresh new game, and you'll wonder how you ever managed without them before.

The legendary game's latest overhaul.

This version compared to HD edition (Released in 2013) brings a new graphics engine to the front, and along with community mods compatibility, offers a lot of customization either for fancier players and those who want the most optimized way to play the game (Not only in the visual department, but also in terms of gameplay).

Definitive edition also comes with extra tutorial missions which helps those who want to get into the classic IA Skirmishes and the Multiplayer. These tutorials come with video explanations about what to do in certain steps of the game, and then they throw you right away into the gameplay, qualifying you by either time spent in the mission or units lost, which helps to measure how good you are doing and how much you want to improve those times.

Last but not least, this version of AoE2 already comes with the expansions that were released for the HD edition, so you are getting already a lot of value by purchasing this one.

This game is, by no means, the original age of empires II. and I do not mean that in a weird nostalgic way that has nothing to do with mechanics or gameplay. you'd be mistaken. This game has some significant tweaks to it, which make it seem more of a "polished product" in hyper-capitalistic times... but it is NOT the original game. Units get confused A LOT because they cannot overlap. so you will see units scramble a lot, to get in the right position to do something. Deliver ressource to building for example. or gather all around the same tree and chop the wood. NOT THAT EASY ANYMORE with this "definitive" edition. Well all i can tell you is that... I am DEFINITIVELY dissapointed. Why would you change a winning team? Why do you not even have the original in the shop? Like... do I now have to go out into the dark underbelly of unlicensed software, to get THE ACTUAL ORIGINAL VERSION of this game? that would be ridiculous.

- Campains' texts and narrating voices lost their original touch
- Trabuchets have 100% precision against walking units....

Age of Empires II holds a special spot in my gaming heart. I first played it back in '99, and it hooked me instantly. While my full playtime isn't on Steam, I can confidently say we need more games like this ‚Äì innovative, not just copy-paste.

If you're thinking about grabbing this classic, do it! Whether solo or with pals, it's a blast. Not too pricey, and it's easy for anyone to pick up. Graphics aren't cutting-edge, but the gameplay is where it shines.

Set in the Medieval Era, choose from various factions - European, Middle Eastern, Asian, and even Native American. Similar units, but each has its unique twist. Ignore the dated graphics, and you're in for a seriously fun time.

In a nutshell: Age of Empires II is a must for anyone craving a throwback RTS from '99. Sure, the graphics are old, but the gameplay? Timeless and awesome. Get it and enjoy the medieval mayhem!

So, after 2000 hours on this version, every achievement obtained, every campaign finished and reaching a respectable ELO on the ladder, i believe I'm entitled to an opinion. I've been playing versions of this game for 15 years now. Nostalgia aside, i do believe this is the greatest game ever made. The diversity of civilisations, strategies, maps, custom scenarios, campaigns and community has truly cemented Age of Empires 2 among the GOATs. The thriving competitive scene coupled with the devoted devs still pushing new content 20 years later has cultivated a devoted fan base that will see this game until its dying breath. For new players, this game can be daunting and challenging. The learning curve is incredibly steep and punishing but also incredibly satisfying when you put together a new skill. Should you buy this game? The answer is always yes. Will you enjoy this game if you enjoy RTS? Absolutely you will, because this game set a bar that will never be rivalled.

This is the only game that I have somewhat consistently played for my entire life. Nothing else even comes close. I received the original Age of Empires II CD as a Christmas present in 1999. I played the original game, original expansion, HD Edition, and now the Definitive Edition. If civ building and army control are your thing then this game is the pinnacle. Civ strengths and weaknesses, unit abilities, and map gens make for a compelling multiplayer experience that never seems to get stale. On-going dev support and quality patches have kept the game fresh and nice to play. Yes, the learning curve will be extremely steep. Check out the biggest Youtubers to figure out build orders and which civs will compliment your playstyle the best. Then go and have a ball!

It's the Age of Empires 2 you know and love - but all freshened up for modern PCs. It's hard to say whether you'd like this game if you have never played the original. But it's also cheap as hell, so only one way to find out!

So don't wait any longer and get this game today!

I have played the game for 24 hours, and have played the HD about 58 hours. I will be reviewing AGE II DE while also mentioning what does it have that's better than HD.

AGE II DE is a RTS strategy game, put in the 5th century, till the end of the 1500s, and the beginning of the renaissance. The game has 45 civilizations (at time of review), as is one of, the best AoE game. The graphics have been made much better, so much better than HD. And Yes, it sometimes crashes, but it happens mostly when people click the cut-scene when opening the game. How I get past the issue, is just by not skipping, and waiting until it ends. If that's not good for you, just wait a second and then skip.

The game, is highly enjoyable, I love to be the Lithuanians (As I am from the country too) due to their good strategy, which is good if mastered. Every civilization is good for itself, and when mastered, is perfect. The pathing, is the only terrible issue, which is annoying to play with. In HD, pathing is great. In DE, not so much.

I enjoy the game so much, I made a review for it, I hope you enjoy the game if you get it. And remember, finish upgrading your blacksmith! Or you will never win!

The game comes with all the civs from previous expansions, new civs unique to this version of AoE 2, a clear visual upgrade, and many quality of life improvements that make the managing aspect of the game less of a hassle, thus making the game overall feel more enjoyable than previous iterations. I've easily had more fun with this game than either the original, or HD versions of AoE 2. 

Another major plus side to this game (imo) is that the AI doesn't cheat in any way, and instead is effectively programmed to use strategies that experienced human players would use, which does a much better job of preparing you to face real opponents than most other games would.

Edit: I felt the need to add that AI teammates in this game are some of the most self sufficient and helpful AI from any game game that I can think of. There have been many times when an enemy AI is attacking me early on in the game at a point where I am not quite prepared for it, and then my AI teammate sends some military units to help me out out of it's own volition. That help allows me to fend off the early initial attacks from AI sometimes, and provides me with the space needed to age up and boom so that we, as a team, can make the enemy AI suffer for it's early aggression later in the game. The AI on harder difficulties feels like it actually has a real intention of winning the game. It's a nice change of pace from strategy games where friendly AI feels virtually useless and is incapable of working well with you.

The game gets new civs through paid DLCs, and then receives substantial balance patches around the same time new civs come out, which tend to change up how most civs in the game are played at least a little bit.

Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition is truly the best way to play this classic game. The original game came out in 1999. A "remaster" called Age of Empires II: HD Edition which added a bit more content and upscaled visuals was released in 2013. Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition, released in 2019, is a remaster with lots of improvements and content expansions. Namely are the graphical enhancements which have remastered sprite work and sharper visuals (also support 4K). In addition, this version adds a lot of quality of life improvements. One such thing is the automatic farm replenishment which was a sorely needed feature. This version features all the campaigns from the previous versions. In addition, this is the only version of the game to feature co-op campaign content which I personally enjoyed a lot.

One thing to note is that this version has a lot of DLC content. The content adds different civilizations and campaigns. The learning curve is fairly easy to pick up since all the civilizations share many overlapping units and gameplay mechanics. Easy to pick up but hard to master. Unlike Age of Empires III or Age of Mythology that has fundamentally different civilizations, these play similarly allowing a fairly balanced pool of civilizations to play with or against. Granted each civilization has its strong points and bonuses as well as some unique units. There are 35 different civilizations in the base game and 45 in total with the DLC. There are also 27 campaign missions in the base game. Additionally, the DLC entitled Return of Rome adds a lot of legacy content from Age of Empires I including all the civilizations from that title.

Age of Empires II is constantly still receiving updates and new content in the form of DLCs. If you are looking for a fun medieval period RTS, you'll find a lot of enjoyment with this one.

Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition
After getting 100% achievements, it's time to give a review.

The graphical difference for the DE vs. HD is pretty well done, with all the reskinned that has been done in this game, supports 4K resolution, improved visuals, fewer but new types of achievements, and two games in one (If you buy the DLC...) new buildings and a better overview.

Now I like doing achievements (BUT!) I don't like doing the same over and over again when it comes to converting, I did it on Age of Empires Definitive Edition (1000 times) and Age of Empires II HD (1000 times again...), and now here as well... I'm okay if it's a few... but come on!!! 1000 plus more again on DE! The creators of this game love the word "Wololo" for some weird reasons... At least I didn't have to lead each faction one hundred times to victory again. (Just once) 

Now you get achievements on some of the campaigns themselves, some of them were pretty hard to get like the one called "Rome was destroyed in one day" where you need to complete the campaign in less than 30 minutes by destroying all the castles in the Roman city. It took me 8-10 tries to do it.

You can also play the Age of Empires Definitive Edition on this called (Return of Rome) with a few changes and new stuff. The Portuguese in this game are way too good with their building called Feitoria. With that building, they can fight forever. Not only that! but if your teammate makes you his enemy for a few seconds, he can convert that building and use it as well. (Only if you don't have LOCKED TEAM on) Sharing is caring, after all.

Now when it comes to multiplayer, I had problems many times when several people tried to join the game which made it very difficult to get the achievement called "Masterpiece" where you have to win over 3 human players alone. I tried playing randomly with 3 and almost got it, but some of the players "rage quit" before finishing them off which ended up with me not unlocking the achievement. Good thing to have friends for this.

They change how the AI plays itself on maps, but you can change it from CD, HD, or DE the way the AI does things. They started making walls! (Haven't seen that before) The game comes with many new challenges on the campaign if you liked playing on easy, now you have to play on "hard difficulty" on some of the campaigns if you want the achievement.

(Overall) Would I recommend this game to you? - Yes
If you want a good strategy, story, build, and fighting game this is the game for you and your friends where you can play several different factions (If you don't mind buying the DLC...)

[b] If you've never touched Age of Empires 2 before: Buy it. No discussion. It's personally and objectively one of the best games ever created. [/b]

* Graphics are what many people expected the HD edition to be; you probably won't like them in the beginning but once you're used to them they're stunningly beautiful plus there are tons of ways to customize it (grid, small trees, mods, ...).

* Audio has been remastered and while I personally don't like some sound effects, they're still really well made.

* Performance has been improved significantly and you can get a smooth 200 frames per second with a decent rig.

* Network performance equally good to Voobly UserPatch from my experience.

* Matchmaking has a rotating map pool (player can vote which maps will be in the next rotation) and you can favourite and ban maps.

* "Mimimi muh ranked lobbies". You can only play ranked through matchmaking, lobbies are unranked. I think that's how it should be for multiple reasons but I don't want to go into detail here.

* There are regular balance patches and with the vast civ pool there will always be a counter to a "strongest" civ so there is rarely a patch where something feels unbeatable.

* QoL features are great but not over the top (e.g. no AoM style auto queue), as Cysion said: More time fighting the enemy instead of the UI. Hardcore AoC players will disagree.

If you're an AoE fan you're probably gonna buy it anyway and if you aren't you should become one.
I feel a lot of new players are just starting their AoE 2 journey so don't hesitate to jump into matchmaking right away. The game has a thriving competitive scene as well and a community always willing to help out new players.

The game features higher resolution textures, improved animations, and enhanced sound effects. This helps to make the game more visually appealing and immersive. It still offers the same engaging real-time strategy experience that made the original game a classic. The inclusion of modern conveniences, such as improved path-finding and unit control has improved a lot. The Definitive Edition includes multiplayer features, allowing players to compete against each other online (Ranked Games). The addition of new content and campaigns, as well as the ability to create and share custom scenarios is much appreciated. The game runs smoothly on a variety of hardware, but the performance may vary depending on individual's system specifications.
P.S. - One of my favourite games of all times. Its a Legacy and a Legendary Game.

Age of Empires 2 will always be my go to recommendation for people who are just starting off with RTS games.  Compared to Starcraft, it is far more forgiving and less stressful. And even if you are not into multiplayer, there are nearly 40 campaigns (each with 5-6 missions) for you to try out. And they're some of the best in the genre.

As for the remake, it adds a ton of Quality of Life improvements and entirely redone graphics that stay true to the original artistic vision. If you have even a remote interest in Strategy games, you owe it to yourself to give this a shot.

And with the constant release of expansions, the content flow doesn't seem to end, and hopefully never will.
