In Spring of 2021, I decided that I finally want to try to git gud at what is likely my favourite game of all time. Maybe in another 2k hours, I will have finally reached that goal.

All joking aside, I had AoE 2 installed on every single computer I've had since 1999, and it has only gotten better. And now with a thriving and highly inclusive competitive Scene, if anything, there is even more reason to love it. Yes, I got quite the beating when I first started playing the ladder, but I also found a tournament specifically for beginners and made more and more friends among the other players. 

And even for players who don't like competitive play in tournaments or on the ranked ladder, I've spent countless hours in the campaigns or the editor, so nobody is forced to play competitively.

I will say though that the competitive scene, especially the local one, has been one of the highlights of my recent years, and I'm very grateful to the players I've met through this game.

AoE II is one of the most important games of my youth. I was seven back then in 1999, and I used to play it a lot. Like really a lot. HD edition from 2013, which is still available on Steam, is excellent, but despite all the new content, the experience was still quite similar to the original version from 1999. At least for me.

This Definitive Edition is something completely different. It‚Äôs this fantastic game from 1999 with entirely new graphics, physics, improved UI, new campaigns, all the additional HD content, and what‚Äôs most important, plenty of quality of life improvements that make gameplay even more enjoyable. It‚Äôs almost like playing AoE II for the first time! Too bad I‚Äôm 20 years older today, and I don‚Äôt have so much time to spend in this game‚Ä¶ 

I won‚Äôt write a huge review, and I won‚Äôt explain what this game is. If you‚Äôre reading this, you know what the Age of Empire is. You‚Äôre just thinking if this DE is worth it or you‚Äôre looking for a reason to buy it. Let me give it to you: it‚Äôs well worth your money, especially with the extra discount for owners of the HD version.

Have fun and [b]wololo[/b]!

[Edit 2022] - They are pushing this game further and further by adding high quality DLCs with amazing content. AoE2 DE is now an ultimate RTS experience with many years of support ahead of us. Keep on keeping on!

[Edit 2023] - Buy it now.

RTS games are all about maintaining your defence, offence and resources. While you strategize a battle plan.

By far AoE takes the cake in this approach, not only do you need to build up the right counter to your opponents army but theirs also small things that can ultimately change the course of the battle such as having a hill advantage, how ever small it maybe you still get a tiny boost to your damage and view range. You can also use castles and towers to shoot the opponents army as your units fight keeping them in the range of fire, you may lose units in the process but they end up losing more.

Armour and weapon upgrades are still the most important for your units survival, so is knowing what counters what. Over all.. you are a commander, are you better then the other one?

Also if you're new to RTS games NO your APM is not important that just means you click real fast, it doesn't mean you know how to out smart your opponent.

Age of Empires 2 Definitive Edition truly lives up to its name. More than just a visually enhanced version of the 1999 classic and the 2013 HD edition, this version improved AI, additional comfort features and reworked campaigns. It is a monster of a game with over a hundred hours of gameplay in any of the 37 campaigns, skirmishes, or any of the several multiplayer modes.
The gameplay could be challenging for all newcomers and beginners. AoE II is a game where defensive structures are very powerful and building up your economy is of paramount importance. For the inexperienced, Youtube and The Art of War are very helpful.
Although personally I was always more of a fan of the first AoE because of its ancient setting, this version of the second game, with all the content and support, simply blows AoE I out of the water. It might just be the best game in the series right now.
Still one of my favourite games! And its still getting updates!

Fantastic game, even though it's over 20 years old. I've been palying it since I was a kid, and still play it when I'm 25. Endless enjoyment from a cheap, simple game that you can lose yourself in.

I played AoC many years back, in happier days when I was just content with placing troops on opposing sides of a river in scenario editor and then having them battle each other in ever escalating conflicts. Picking up the new definitive edition is one of the best decisions I've made, it scratches a big RTS itch for me.

I mostly play singleplayer, the campaigns are really diverse and mostly fun. However there is the odd mission which requires playing in a really meta-gamey way and you [i]have[/i] to play in a specific manner to finish the mission. Something like "build a castle in this spot ASAP to thwart infinite enemy waves" or "build 4 TCs as soon as the game starts to jump-start your eco" and you can't figure this out without looking it up from the wiki.

Other than minor gripes like these the mechanics hold up, the game has a constant influx of balance patches and new content updates and it is in the best place possible, very dynamic and entertaining for a game that was originally released nigh 2 decades ago.

The single player works well enough except that allies almost never build markets in time for you to win a game on high difficulty, and asking them to build a market only results in them telling you to give them wood, and even if you do, they almost never still build a market. Very frustrating. Any team game with an AI ally should automatically build a market, especially if you take the time to tell them to.  The multi-player is TERRIBLE.  The wait time for matches isn't bad, usually 2-4 minutes, but players are often bots I think and on a good day 1 out of 4 games will involve all players actually playing, and on a bad day 6/7 games (yes, six out of seven on average) will be 2v2, 3v3, or 4v4 games where players either resign within the first few minutes or never begin playing at all. Very frustrating and these games obviously end in a one-sided and unfair victory.  I think Microsoft uses bots to pose as players sometimes but to be honest I can't be sure... its strange how often players on your team won't communicate with you when you talk to them so I don't know what else to think. All-in-all the experience has been very bad in both Ranked and Un-Ranked play.  I LOVE this game, really, and I wish it worked worth a crud, but it doesn't.  If I could play it offline over LAN with other people, then that might work but I have no friends who play this unfortunately. As it is, trying to get in and play competitively online with random strangers JUST DOES NOT WORK like it does for a lot of other big-title games. I also wish that the online maps that were popular were, well, maps that I like.  I often like big coastal maps with standard play-style (no strange mods or weird rules about how many times your civ can upgrade certain upgrades, etc) but apparently playing the game "normally" is an oddity that rarely anyone but me enjoys, I guess.

Faithful remaster of a classic game, retaining the artstyle, the iconic soundtrack and even adding QOL changes as well as new content in the form of campaigns and civilizations. 

This was one of the first games I played, and the devs truly managed to retain the feel of the original when creating this game. They keep balacing the game and adding content to this day, and the new civilizations feel fresh without feeling out of place.

If you like RTS or classic games, this one is a must!

Amazing game, my father played the AoE Franchise ever since the first game came out, and we decided to buy the definitive edition of his favorite one. Would recommend it to anyone who enjoys strategy games.

I bought AoE 2 DE in 2019 to play a little bit of the campaigns to start with, just because I wanted to reexperience some of the great moments from when I was a young adult. While I played the French campaign and playing on "Standard" I got absolutely crushed by the AI and stopped playing relatively shortly after because I wasn't just very good at adapting my strategy but I primised that I'd return to the game to try again eventually.

Cue 2021 and I tried again but this time I had made myself a promise to try harder, get the basics right and do some achievements as well. The tutorials and "training missions" ( like "Art of War" ) helped me understand the mistakes I made and play better in the campaigns.

Over the next couple of months, I played through all the campaigns - new and old - and also tried doing it on harder difficulties eventually with some of the missions maybe taking multiple tries to beat but what I got out of the game was a fantastic experience that challenged me but also entertained me for hundreds of hours.

Cue 2023 and I return yet again to play and finish the newly released campaigns from the new DLCs.

I've yet to play a ranked game, but the campaigns in and off themselves are worth every little penny. Missions can range from "Keep your units safe and win like in a RPG", "Build your base and destroy all enemies" to "Defend while the enemies assault you", it has one of the best mission variety out of any RTS game I played in my life.

"Age of Empires 2: Definitive Edition", is an old classic that's dressed in new clothes with a lot of good Quality of life improvements but in its core kept the gameplay tight, just like it was when it originally released. Of course, some changes have been made in terms of balance, with new civilizations being added over the released DLCs and multiple different patch / release versions broadening the amount of choices the player has for both ranked and campaign games. I appreciate a lot that each new civilization gets their own campaign, so you can actually try them out in a scripted setting offline while not putting any pressure on the player either. Skirmish matches against AI do exist if you don't like to play the campaign and rather prepare yourself for online multiplayer - with varying degrees of difficulty to be chosen by you during the creation of said skirmish match.

I cannot recommend this game enough if you love RTS games, as it has so much content and plays so well with the improvements, it's tough to find anything better in this day and age, that not only gets supported constantly but also still has a lively community. 

And, if you don't enjoy playing online yourself, you can find Twitch streams of tournaments for example to watch and root for your favorite player while you can just enjoy the chaos by top players. Additionally there are also players / casters on Twitch that stream related content like lower-skilled players battling each other or even playing themselves.

All in all, a fantastic game with a great base of what makes a RTS game timeless even now.

One of the greatest RTS games of all time (TOP ONE IMHO) got a reboot that included a full expansion, Dedicated Servers plus new visuals for everything and balance changes, all for the price of a normal expansion pack (with a discount for aoe2HD owners). About this game nothing says more than the fact that is game is the pure form of an RTS game with basic rules and gameplay for new players to learn while being amazingly hard to master, being a pure form of an RTS and with an intent to balanced and fair gameplay there are minimum differences between factions so all much-ups between them are fair. The game focuses on both a heavy economy side as well as a military one that need to be well rounded for a successful game. Economy in this game is divided from worker numbers and build orders up to micro managing every single villager (for example a well placed mining camp and villagers on the correct side can make a huge difference for production), military focuses mostly on unit types and counters while costs timing and effective use of the units that comes with experience gives an edge to more experienced players even in uphill battles. The game also hosts a number of historical campaigns that scale from easiest to hard for everyone to enjoy and get himself a challenge, there is also battles vs AI (6 difficulty scaling options) for fun friend games or to practicing to join the MP scene. Overall this game even 20+ years old still remains a master piece on the RTS game roster with DE being it's most successful installation.

80/100 -Thumb down is due to their text chat being way to over censored can't even say "umm" it's ridiculous so thumbing down in protest of this but anyway...

I wouldn't call this a Definitive Edition but fairly good job apart from a few things that grind my gears

Cons
-No LAN play
-No Peer to Peer Play over the internet, if they shutdown the severs for maintenance or shut them down like they did with the original then no more multiplayer + Peer to Peer can make matches more even for some people as both players suffer lag, where when both players connect to a sever one player will have more lag than the other
-In game chat way over censored, should be an option to turn on or off, if not choose what words to turn on or not or just an option to mute a player or something but it's crazy stupid & censors such words even like dock when there is a dock in game
-No Classic game mode
-Exclusive time limited events with in game items, shouldn't be limited, in no way is that good for the consumer
-Would also be nice to see more post match statistics, like vil idle time, TC & Castle construction + destruction etc etc

Pros
-Pretty well balanced RTS, good paper & scissors mechanics 
-Easy to pick up, hard to master
-Every game is different

This is the best way you can spend money on this platform. Greatest strategy game of all time and it's hard to believe it is still updated and taken care off after all these years.

DLCs are a bit overpriced for what they offer (1-3 civs when you already have few dozens for free, and some campaigns), but for a game with no micro-transactions, i think it's fine to give away few more bucks to support developers (and buy them on sale).

November 2023 Update

As of now, the game is in almost an unplayable state. The moron asshole morons that make this game clearly have no idea what they are doing in any capacity whatsoever. Here are the highlights:

1. Pathing: The pathing for units is the worst it has ever been. Morons. Villagers completely stop building queued buildings. And I mean completely; they stop and do nothing. Attack move doesn't work. Patrol doesn't work. Defensive stance doesn't work. Moron idiot assholes. 

2. AI: The AI as a teammate still deletes its market(s) much of the time. Why? Moron idiot asshole developers. And, a new trick is that an AI teammate will only trade with the closest ally, often the player. This severely impedes that AI player's gold intake and effectively disables them. Worthless developers. 

3. Balance: The Georgians have a bad win rate in ranked online 1v1 as of now. That is but one small subset of the game. That civ is an absolute nightmare in death matches and empire wars. Their unique cavalry unit is also bugged. Unreal. 

Do not buy or play this game. 

As of late May 2023, here are the debilitating issues that make the game almost unplayable: 

1. The crashes. They made the anti-cheating software build in to this game so sensitive that it crashes the program many, many times per session. The idiot asshole morons who made the anti-cheat think things like Google Chrome, Windows antivirus, Firefox, and Steam itself are cheat programs that warrant crashing the game. 

2. The AI is still stupid as shit. My allies trade with exclusively me, regardless of my proximity to them. Is my base exactly next to my ally? Doesn't matter! They are trading with me to the exclusion of any other teammate, even if the trade route generates next to no gold. Morons. The AI as a teammate still does super fun and excellent things like delete their market and not build another one. Sometimes, they wholesale stop doing anything. I call it the bozo protocol. That's what the developers are constantly in, apparently; the bozo protocol. 

3. They have broken so many elements of the game that I lost count. Villagers will go full dipshit mode and either take forever to build multiple buildings, or will stop building things during building operations all together. The patrol and attack move functions also are almost completely broken right now, too. If something is patrolling or moving-and-attacking and it catches and kills a unit, it stops its patrol or attack move. This obviates the entire purpose of those commands. Morons. 

Overall, the game somehow manages to have worse stability, functionality, and AI than it did years or even decades ago. How they messed all of this up, and continuously fail to fix it, is beyond me. I wish I could be as stupid as the assholes that make this game. It must be liberating to have no accountability because everyone knows you are too stupid to be held responsible for real things.

When i was 8 years old, still remember the first time i launched the first Age Of Empires in 1997 on a windows 95 PC. Lots of fun memories of the Age Of Empires games. Both the solo and multiplayer games. LAN parties with friends. A  trip down memory lane. Age Of Empires has always been a part of my life. It is a beautiful game for both young and old, if you are playing this game for the first time I recommend the William Wallace Campaing. You will gradually get a better understanding of the controls and basic strategy without feeling like you are playing a Tutorial. 

So overall, great music, great solo and multiplayer gameplay. I'm glad that Age Of Empires is still appreciated by so many people and that Age of Empires is still played very actively.

Ah, Age of Empires 2 Definitive Edition, you old rascal, you! It's incredible how a game that's older than some ancient civilizations can still hold its ground and make me feel like a conqueror with a laptop instead of a sword. Here's my two cents on this time-traveling strategy extravaganza.

First of all, let's talk about the graphics. The Definitive Edition has given this classic game a facelift that even Cleopatra would envy. The once-pixelated warriors and buildings now look sharper than my mother-in-law's criticisms, and the landscapes are more vibrant than a medieval tapestry on steroids. I'm telling you, I had to resist the urge to touch the screen and feel the silky smooth textures of my virtual empire.

But the real magic lies in the gameplay. It's like a never-ending chess match where you're not just moving pieces but commanding armies, building castles, and slinging insults at your enemies in the chat. From the humble beginnings of your little town to the booming civilization that spans continents, Age of Empires 2 Definitive Edition lets you live out your dreams of world domination without the pesky consequences of actual warfare. Who needs real-life battles when you can send an army of Teutonic Knights to wipe out your friend's puny village?

Speaking of friends, the multiplayer experience is a barrel of laughs and surprises. It's like a medieval-themed reality show where alliances are made and broken, and diplomacy is as reliable as a trebuchet made by a blindfolded engineer. Just when you think you've secured a friendship pact, your so-called ally sends an army of elephants crashing through your defenses. The betrayal stings worse than being hit by an arrow right in the horse's rump.

Now, let's address the AI. Oh boy, the AI. They're like cunning medieval geniuses one moment and complete dimwits the next. It's as if they learned military strategy from a toddler playing with wooden blocks. Sometimes they march into battle with the precision of a synchronized dance routine, and other times they get stuck in a corner of the map, futilely banging their swords against a tree. But hey, it's all part of the charm, right? I mean, who doesn't want to witness a pack of knights galloping headfirst into a forest?

In conclusion, Age of Empires 2 Definitive Edition is a timeless gem that combines historical accuracy with comedic chaos. It's the kind of game that can make you feel like Genghis Khan one minute and an overzealous architect the next. So gather your friends, sharpen your wit, and get ready to build an empire that will stand the test of time, or at least until someone accidentally sets the town center on fire. Trust me, it's happened.

P.S. Don't blame me if you start seeing knights and castles in your dreams. That just means you're becoming a true medieval conqueror. Embrace it with force!

A simple but detailed explanation of why, after having played both versions, I prefer Definitive Edition (DE) instead of 2013 Edition:

-2013 Edition's farms don't automatically re-seed, forcing you to either order your villagers to re-seed them, or to mash the "queue re-seed" button in the mill. In DE, you can set the mills to automatically re-seed.
-Definitive Edition lets you shift-click construction orders just like in 2013 Edition, but in the latter, the villager will move to build the last building you placed down. If you order several buildings, they will stop constructing the building they're already working on to go build the new one. In DE they will wait to finish the first building before starting on the next one.
-2013 Edition's unit sprites are very pixelly and hard to distinguish one type of infantry unit from another, and to a lesser extent, one team from another. DE's graphics are much clearer so it is very easy to distinguish unit type/team.
-Definitive Edition is far, FAR more customizable than 2013 Edition. Not just with the settings (graphics, UI, and controls are much more changeable) but especially with creating a game, namely win conditions, starting conditions, map sizes, unit restrictions, etc. You can adjust many more settings to make a new game into whatever kind of scenario you want. Also you can see what the map types actually look like in DE.
-Definitive Edition has noticeably better pathfinding than 2013 Edition.
-In DE you can zoom in and out. In 2013 Edition you can't.
-In DE you can queue build orders while simultaneously upgrading the building. In 2013 Edition you can't even see any build options while a building is in the middle of upgrading.
-In DE you can tell scouts to automatically scout out the map.
-In DE the HUD shows you how many villagers are working on each resource. 2013 Edition does not do this, you have to play hide and seek with each one to count them.
-The soundtrack for DE has more faction-specific songs, as well as less repetitive music. Both game's soundtracks are good, but I find having the DE soundtrack playing in the background to be more enjoyable. This point is pure preference.
-2013 Edition's graphics are nice if you enjoy the old-school style, but DE's graphics are significantly easier on the eyes and prettier.
-Definitive Edition has more civilizations.
-Definitive Edition is just as moddable and has a very passionate modding community.
-Definitive Edition seems to have more balanced gameplay.

The civilization list is insane now, and the community is probably in the best shape that it's been in a long time. I usually just play with friends, so I can't speak for the balancing of civs, but I do know the developer cares and they are constantly working on that.

Undeniably a classic, which defined its genre, and remained alive for two decades exclusively due to the community's dedication, of those of us who never forgot it. Now, it rises again, in even greater splendour, like a phoenix from the ashes, to receive the full recognition it had always deserved, but not yet already received.

This edition, particularly, is an exemple of how to remake a game without adulterating it: bringing "quality of life" improvements such as the self-reseeding farms, and moderatly and coherently innovating, from the new civilizations and the balancing of old ones, to aesthetic issues such as making full songs out of the very short civilizations' leitmotiven of the original game. Not to mention the Art of War intermediate tutorials which teach players who already know the basics of playing the basics of how to play well.

All this and much more - notably the continuing updates it's been receiving since it's been launched - entitle it to be called a Definitive Edition, of a work of art which will hardly ever get old. Very high and safe return on investment here.

I have played this game for most of my life at this point. The development team continues to tweak and improve it, the DLC expands the game and adds hours upon hours of single player goodness. It's harder to play with friends than it was due to the march of time, but I honestly can't see a time when I'll ever go a year without loading up AoE2.

Original Review Below:

I mostly play online with my friends and, as our time has been limited by adulthood, we usually stick to team games against the AI. In HD, this was usually a matter of whittling them down over time, even against hardest. The new extreme AI erases that advantage and makes us have to think instead of just vomit the same units at them. They rebuild in different areas and employ player-like strategies to counter you. The rest of the game is great, the graphics are gorgeous, but the AI is what really brings me to love this version of AoE2 over all others. I'd gladly pay more than full price on this for the AI alone.

Everyone can enjoy this game, no matter your skill level. The music is amazing, storytelling is great and the game mechanics are almost flawless. There are many challenging campaigns, both solo and co-op. Both are a lot of fun. The AI is definitely much smarter in the DE and any difficulty above hard needs a pretty decent APM in a standard map like Arabia, 
I first played this game when 20 years back, and I have always come back to play it again every now and again. This is one of those games I never uninstall. One last thing.. "beware the Kara-Khitai, they are without honor".

Worthy of the title "Definitive Edition", and irrefutable proof that Age of Empires 2 has stood the test of time.

I never thought I'd still be playing this game over 20 years after its original release. It may have taken a while to get to this point, but the Definitive Edition is a perfect example of how to update a game to the modern day. It is packed full of content even for a multiplayer-avoider like me, and it somehow looks gorgeous despite having the same 20-year-old aesthetic. A tangible effort has gone into rebalancing and updating everything, while keeping the changes and new stuff as true to the original design as possible (DLC civs are a small exception as they tend to get some fancy stuff).

As a chronic campaign player, I do wish there was a better indicator of the quality and difficulty of each campaign, especially the ones carried over from HD Edition as most(all?) of them have been redesigned. There is a big difference between a 'good' campaign(interesting objectives/design and an actual AI economy) and a 'bad' one(glorified skirmish battles and/or infinite enemy resources) and it's hard to tell which is which until you're neck deep in them. And there are a LOT of campaigns.

Speaking of that, difficulty settings have sucked for me in both campaign and skirmish vs AI. Standard is often too easy and makes the AI highly passive, while Moderate skyrockets AI aggression and forces me to play in a more urgent, stressful way in order to keep up. I don't want to play harder than is comfortable keeping my APMs up just to stand a chance... if only I could split the difference somehow.
Good game but hard. Thanks!

The absolute basement pits of gaming.

I have been playing computer/video games for around 30 years now, and this game is the absolute worst game I have ever had the misfortune to encounter. It is not even remotely close. This game is the basement pits of gaming in every regard. The AI is atrocious. Units will completely ignore attacking enemy units in favour of swinging a sword or firing a crossbow at a house or mill, and will not engage the attacker udner any circumstance. Pathing is appaling, the formation system is intended to enable groups of units to move around in a semi realistic manner, but what actually happens is your big long line of pike just wheel in place or reform endlessly while being turned into mulch by firearms. 
	Enemy AI units are "just better" because "reasons" - the same unit with the same technologies and same upgrades will have roughly double the range of yours, double the power and be virtually unkillable. Watching 60 hand cannon die to one AI hand cannon as they wheel about helplessly or shoot at a farm instead is not particularly fun to watch.
	It's also almost impossible to attack the correct thing, densely built up enemy fortresses cheese the isometric view by making it impossible to attack guard towers, you instead have to kill everything around the guard tower before you can even have your units click on it. All the while the guard tower is just sweeping a giant laser beam of arrows across your army.

Remember when we used to play on the Zone, then they shut down, then we went to gamespy, then to gameranger and voobly, now the game has it own servers ingame. Graphics? Aged like a vintage meme, but in a good way. While others try to outshine, AOE II sits on its strategy throne, sipping pixel-perfect tea.

To the successors: nice try, but you're the sidekicks in this epic saga. This game's the Gandalf of strategy ‚Äì you shall not pass its greatness.

In a world of strategy, Age of Empires II is the boss, the legend, the Chuck Norris of gaming. Conquer the medieval madness, laugh at the wannabes, and remember ‚Äì empires rise, empires fall, but AOE II stays winning. Ready for a strategy party? Command on, Commander!

[h1]The Game of the Ages[/h1]

The classic RTS that came out in 1999 makes a return in its most fantastic iteration yet! When I was in high school we didn't have internet, so all I ever did was play games against the AI and design elaborate custom maps that nobody would ever play except for myself. [i]Which always felt kind of like I was cheating against the AI, since I knew where everything was going to be ahead of time![/i]

Nowadays online play against both single opponents and teams is an option with different queues for ranked and unranked games, in addition to co-op campaigning with a friend or just teaming up on the AI in a custom game room. There's a huge and thriving community around the game with sponsored tournaments and even professional players, streamers with thousands of subscribers on Twitch, and community events for us casual players to enjoy some shenanigans. 

I love that the bulk of the community is over the age of 20, too. Something about the art style and real-time strategic gameplay appeals more to us adults than to the kiddos, and it's nice to know that when I play online my opponent is more likely to be fifty than twelve. I've had enough childish nonsense from players in other games, this community is like a breath of fresh air from that, though you do still get your occasional idiot. The plethora of different civilizations keep the game from ever getting stale, yet the commonalities between them make trying a new one less intimidating than in other, similar games. No matter what "civ" you "random" into if you elect to choose random, you have some idea what to do if you've played any other.

[b]Low skill floor, high skill ceiling.[/b] Game is rife with "Kirbyisms" in that regard, if anybody is familiar with the term. :)

I highly recommend this video game, especially for people that have an interest in medieval civilisations. The game has hundreds of hours of campaigns covering mostly real events in various continents. Campaign missions function almost like free-form puzzles in which you have to apply you knowledge of the game's mechanics to find a appropriate and effective solution to the mission's challenge. If structured campaigns are not your interest, however, the game also offers a skirmish mode where you can fight against 1 or up to 7 AIs using conditions and maps of your choosing. With over 30 civilisations (and counting), each with their own unique units and buildings, skirmish mode battles can be varied and interesting each time and provide a source, at least for me, of infinite entertainment because, much like chess, it just never gets boring to play. In terms of the difficulty of the AI, I would say that it can present a considerable challenge if you play against hard, hardest or extreme. I will say, at first, it can be difficult to even defeat moderate AI because, especially if you're new to RTS games, the game can require lots of macro and micro management of units, particularly in the dark and feudal age where you have to properly and efficiently manage your villagers to the right resources or risk aging up to slowly and being demolished by a castle age or late feudal age opponent. Luckily, you can find build orders online to give you an idea of what to do in the first 10-15 mins of the game. Similar to chess, the game has common 'openings' you can try that set your economy up for a certain type of play. Examples are: fast castle, fast imperial, man-at-arms rush, archer rush, scout rush, dark age rush or tower rush. In terms of visual presentation, I think the game looks amazing. The game is an isometric format and while units and buildings are neither realistic nor cartoony, but they are very clear and have, much like chess pieces, designs that are distinct and easy to identify. This is important because units all have counter units, so it is necessary to be able to quickly identify the unit your up against and respond with the correct counter unit. In terms of support, the game is constantly getting updates, quality of life changes, and even new civilisations and campaigns via DLC. I cannot speak at the moment about multiplayer because I do not play it; however, I know that it has a relatively large multiplayer scene and that its ranked matches mode tries to pair you with players on a similar level to you. I will say that this game is not really one that you can just open up a first time and be good at (unless you are already well versed in RTS games) and even after 250 hrs I'm still not that great at it at all (not that that affects the fun factor too much). The campaigns are much more forgiving, but it terms of skirmish against the AI at hard-extreme difficulty, or real players, be prepared to lose quite often initially...perhaps even in catastrophic fashion. If you keep at it, however, the games mechanics will eventually click and by then you will have a game that can provide endless entertainment whilst stimulating your brain, much like chess.

A game which has stood the test of time for 25 years since release and has continued to see success, revolution, and enjoyment, having itself defined much of the RTS genre the world over. I have owned this game on CD since 2004, and have put many hundreds of hours into it when I should've been doing homework. That all-time game I spoke of was Age Of Empires 2, and this game is Age of Empires 2- Definitive Edition. And I would say with certainty that it is Definitely the most and best Age of Empires game we may ever see. Please play this game.

Just perfect

This game saved my life.

I am 42.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Prepare to ditch your social life, forget about the outside world, and potentially ruin relationships with Age of Empires 2. It's not just a game; it's a magnet that sucks you into an alternate universe where time ceases to exist. You might start playing at 8 pm and suddenly realize it's 4 am, and you're still battling William Wallace in the tutorial.

The depth of this game is like an endless pit‚Äîjust when you think you've mastered it, a new strategy smacks you in the face and humbles you. You'll go from proudly boasting your invincible army of Paladins to shamefully staring at the remnants of your decimated civilization, wondering where it all went wrong. It's a rollercoaster of emotions, from triumph to despair, in the span of a few well-placed trebuchet shots.

The gameplay is as captivating as a car crash. You'll find yourself micromanaging your villagers like a frantic puppeteer, coaxing them to gather resources faster than a squirrel hoarding nuts for winter. But don't get too comfortable. Just when you think you've secured victory, an army of berserkers crashes through your gates, making you reconsider your life choices and your faith in the reliability of stone walls.

The game's unpredictability is like a sneaky thief in the night‚Äîjust when you think you've fortified your defenses, it steals your relics, burns your crops, and insults your mother. It's a constant test of your wits, reflexes, and your ability to come up with excuses for why you missed your friend's birthday party (sorry, my castle got sieged, can't leave now).

In conclusion, Age of Empires 2 isn't just a game; it's a journey through the depths of your own sanity. With its addictive gameplay and unforgiving challenges, it's a surefire way to test your relationships, your patience, and your resolve. Enter at your own risk, and be prepared to emerge as either a triumphant conqueror or a broken shell of your former self.

Age of Empires 2 was a fun game to play when I first got it, and remained even so when I got the first version on Steam. So I was delighted to get the Definitive Edition when it was released. I like the improved graphics and the ability to unlock achievements for my Xbox Live Account, as well as the inclusion of all the expansions.

I'm glad this game doesn't crash at all, compared to AoE:DE with that bug - and that the developers closed off the loophole on achievements with cheat codes. The fact the game has had room to include more content than the original was a surprise, what with a new DLC that was made for it recently.

Overall, one of the better Definitive Edition remakes by Microsoft Studios, and still a fun game to play from time to time.

Craziest niche community out of any game I've ever played. I don't have any of the nostalgia because I never played this as a kid, but oh man is this is classic. The gameplay is fairly simple, which is why I think it's so appealing and accessible, yet there's a massive skill ceiling and thousands of different ways to play. There's hundreds upon hundreds of hours of gameplay in the singleplayer campaigns, sandbox modes, and custom scenarios alone, PLUS online multiplayer, and you can also question your capabilities in ranked multiplayer like many modern games, or play team ranked if you truly want to destroy your will to live. Side-note: taunting your enemies (or teammates) with voicelines will never not be funny, and SHOULD be done. After 25 years this game is still getting continuous updates and expansions, which somehow still find ways to freshen up the gameplay and maintain balance across a large roster of civilizations (35 in the base game, and currently 10 more in DLC). I should also mention that the "classic" civs included in the base game are still extremely competitive, with some being the best in the game, so don't feel like you are at a disadvantage for not purchasing the DLC civs. Overall, 10/10, would get castle rushed on Arena and panic because my defenses aren't set up yet on Arena again.

Not only a classic, but after 20 years of updates it's quite possibly the most polished RTS of all time.
Campaigns?  Dozens!
Tutorials?  Duh.
Tutorials that teach you advanced play?  Absolutely!
Multiplayer? Duh.
Co-Op?  Yeah, they even have co-op campaigns.
Custom maps and mods?  Many.
Hotkeys?  Intuitive.
Visuals?  Gorgeous.  I didn't care for the harsh look of the original game, but Definitive Edition is truly beautiful.
Sound?  Timeless.
Music?  Iconic.  Not my personal favorite tbh, usually I listen to other music while playing.

I would recommend this to RTS newcomers, and there's not much reason for veterans to leave.

It took me a long while to get to the point where i enjoy playing. Hotkey practice was really helpful in making my playtime fast enough to not get called a noob in lobby. I think its important to let players know what theyll need to prep themselves for playing, and that has to be found in a lot of the periphery, but thats super easy to find since this is a game from two decades ago. I really like playing spanish. I hope you enjoy this game but you should definitely look into practicing against hard mode AI before jumping in lobbies. itll just be more fun. Also make sure to make more than one type of unit if you can. When I run Conquis I also have some seige units to give a good back up to a conquistador barrage, especially against buildings. Anyways I really wanted to give a review when i FELT like I play consistently enough to like it. And that time has come. Thanks for being a great game, AoE 2

The best RTS game in existence, full stop.  If you like RTS games or are considering buying one, buy this one.  It is slower paced than most RTS games you'll find out there, but I personally think that's a good thing.  Age of Empires was the game that defined what an RTS is supposed to be, back in the late 90s.  Over 20 years later, it is still the best.

The Definitive Edition is a large graphics update, but it also includes more civilizations to play as and more campaigns to play; it is much more mod-friendly than prior versions as well.  There is more, but those are most important.  I have been playing this game since the late 90s when I was a wee little tike.  The amount of total hours I have spent in this game must be over 10,000 hours; and that's probably low-balling it.  I play with my family and single player.  I do not like playing competitively online with RTS games, so I have stayed away from that so far.

25 years and still going strong.  That's really all you need to know.  Microsoft has actively tried to kill this game on at least 3 separate occasions in order to move its gamer base to other games.  Each time it has failed, so they finally embraced the fact that Age II is too good to die, and began supporting it with DE.  For the old gamers that remember the days of MSN Gaming Zone, playing in the Medieval Siege lobby, to the dark days of Voobly, to Ensemble Studios HD version, to now, DE on steam...this game has endured, and will continue to endure for the foreseeable future.  Newer games come and go, but this one endures.  It is at the absolute peak of what an RTS can be.

They keep bring out DLCs without fixing the pathfinding, in game friend system, or map pooling. Banned maps sometimes appear and they keep matchmaking UK players with Chinese players who you cannot talk to. Insufficient punishment for early game quitters in 4v4 and those matches become a coin toss. Open maps difficult to play due to the counter system being paper, scissors & rock with not enough time to react.

I have been watching the movement of units and villagers. I am convinced that my time has been largely wasted believing that you can actually get good at this game by moving your units accordingly so they do as they are told... they do not. Villagers constantly get stuck and take horrible long way rounds and can't even walk in a straight line anymore.

Attack move is broken, units manically dance around huge clumps of melee units and then sometimes attack. Aggressive stance is random and luck based and trying to micro each single unit is extremely difficult due to drag boxes being too big.

The pathfinding is getting more noticeable and unforgivable - this gives huge advantages to projectile archers and fast building castles + trebs, and making late game battles extremely messy with melee troops unable to make up their minds in the chaos.

But i'm insulted. Reselling Age of Empires 1 for the THIRD time at such a stupid price plus keep bringing out DLCs every months that are P2W, splitting the player base between those fanboys who will suck up to anything and the casuals who simply want better AOE2.

No. I will not be converted anymore. I have researched heresy.

Out of 10 games friend got disconnected 8 times. When he doesn't get disconnected the game runs like shit. Despite passing the performance test fps keeps dropping below 20 in some games. Despite being a complete overhaul costing 30$ the game runs worse than ever.

The UI is terrible. The menus simply do not work most of the time. It's things like not being able to see which civilisation your teammate picked or the countdown not being skipped despite everyone being ready.

Do not buy. Another example of a cash-grab remake being worse than the original.

If this is a game that had come out, been fondly remembered during its time as one of the RTS greats, and just been re-released as is, that would have been fine.

But they decided to give it an HD re-release with added content and enhanced visuals and UI. If they had just done that, the game would have been beloved as an amazing remaster and things would have been fine.

But they chose not to stop there. They decided to release another improved re-release, adding even more content, making full-on expansions for a game that came out decades ago, continuing to do balance tuning and support even though this game has had multiple sequels since then. At any time they could have abandoned this game, but they are continuing to support and nurture it. And that is why despite me not being able to play it worth a nickel I will gladly acknowledge AOE2 as one of the greatest in the RTS genre

Age of Empires II, or as I fondly call it, "The Medieval Mirthquake," is like that historical sitcom you've always wanted but set in the Middle Ages. It's a journey through time where you'll build kingdoms, wage epic battles, and occasionally get a chuckle out of the absurdity of it all.

From the moment you step into the medieval world of Age of Empires II, you'll find yourself in a setting that's as historically accurate as a knight in shining rubber armor. Sure, you've got castles, armies, and epic siege weapons, but you've also got monks that can convert war elephants and trebuchets that can fling cows. It's like a history book, but with a sprinkle of absurdity.

The graphics are like a tapestry that's been run through a time machine set to "comedy." The medieval landscapes are filled with jesters, knights in bathrobes, and kings who talk like they've had too much mead. It's like walking through a Renaissance faire where the jesters are the real rulers.

Gameplay is the heart and soul of Age of Empires II's comedy. You'll gather resources faster than a turkey leg disappears at a carnival and send armies into battles that resemble a medieval food fight. It's like running a kingdom with all the strategic prowess of a well-timed pie toss.

The variety of civilizations is like a buffet of caricatures. Whether you lead the Vikings, the Byzantines, or the Teutons, each civilization comes with its unique quirks and units that are as unconventional as a catapult filled with rubber chickens. It's like playing dress-up with a closet full of medieval madness.

The campaigns are like epic tales that don't take themselves too seriously. You'll be part of stories filled with legendary heroes, epic battles, and the occasional twist that makes you wonder if the game's writers were indeed jesters in disguise. It's like being in a medieval sitcom where you're the hero, and the script is full of delightful surprises.

The community is a gathering of history enthusiasts who enjoy adding their own comedic twist. Whether you're sharing tales of your catapulted cows or discussing the absurdity of the in-game voices, Age of Empires II players are like a comedy club audience, ready to share a laugh.

In conclusion, Age of Empires II is not just a game; it's a medieval comedy stage where you can rewrite history with a humorous twist. It's a chance to lead your armies into absurd battles, to build kingdoms with a sprinkle of silliness, and to conquer the ages while sharing a chuckle. So, if you've ever dreamt of leading a parade of jesters into battle or launching flaming sheep at your enemies, Age of Empires II is the medieval mirthquake you've been waiting for. It's time to don your jesters' cap, lead your quirky army, and conquer the ages with laughter. To history and hilarity!

Hands down, this game is the best:
- Definitive Edition of any game made up until now
- strategy game of all time next to Starcraft 2, which is legendary on its own terms
- sandbox of a strategy game with endless possibilities to play with
- still supported game of this era, still recieving new DLC's, still recieving new patches, always getting better (especially considering that its still run on its original Spaghetti code from 1999 and built upon that)
- and most wide-ranging game of its type ever made (there are about 10 immediately playable gamemodes right out of the box on "Skirmish" single player, which of course are also playable in multiplayer
- and (mostly) historically accurate campaign-simulator of all time (and every single of these handcrafted campaigns has its own feel)
- (in my opinion) and most interesting strategy game to be watched live or in VODs (Starcraft has fixed maps so there's less adaptation)

The only thing, AoE2DE is still lacking is more playable Coop-Campaigns. I would even pay for more of them as singular DLCs since they are loads of fun to play with friends.

I will always support and play this game until the end of times. <3

It's age of Empires. It's really hard to put into words for a review but... This game came out in 1999 and look at the attention, love and fanbase it still has. So much of that is new players as well, not just born out of nostalgia. It's a case of hitting it out of the park when it came to the RTS Genre to be balanced, fun, engaging and even historically accurate (all things considering) in a way that any game of any era wishes it could be to hold onto that kind of longevity.

Is it genre defining? I'm not sure that it is, that there's any one thing in particular that makes Age of Empires 2 so amazing in terms of a RTS, but it represents the absolute best that a game can provide overall.

It's name is synonymous with the genre at this point and it's outlived every other horse in the race, including those intended by their own developers to replace it. As they say, lightning doesn't strike twice.

Brilliant game. Xbox Studios have managed to incorporate new civilisations and game play mechanics whilst staying true to the original AoE II. For new players, however, AoE II DE (like the original version) is difficult to get to grips with.

This version is growing on me, with the quality of life improvements like queuing up actions and auto reseeding farms pushing me to recommend this game. However, some things I don't enjoy are the soulless UI, the way they changed the history music, and the mod browser. I am also somewhat jarred by the way they emphasise multiplayer much more than they did with HD and CD, or at least more in your face, however that is more my personal taste. All in all this is a good edition of AoE2, and it seems to be truly the 'definitive' edition in the eyes of the fanbase already.

Edit: I love how they abandoned AOE1 DE so they just decided to add the Romans to this one instead. Typical.

Age of Empires II
This is a game that I grew up playing in Middle School during computer class. We would have LAN Parties where one side of the room would fight against the other.

I don't really remember the story campaign, or whether or not I ever finished it. I only remember the skirmishes that took place even if the details elude me. I bought Age of Empires II Definitive Edition to support the work they put into it. I bought Age of Empires II HD because I had thought it would be a good walk down memory lane.

I'll pass a recommend to the game for bringing back good memories and, perhaps, an agreement that I've moved on from RTS Games. I don't have the reaction time, or the attention span, that I used to have growing up. My ability to focus on multiple things at the same time simply isn't there but Age of Empires II still holds up to current-gen games. 

If your looking for a solid RTS with near infinite replay-ability? Age of Empires II has you covered.
If your looking for a sold RTS with historical campaigns which may, or may not, be stretched in truth while detailing certain events that took place. Age of Empires II has you covered.

I'm not much for paying full price for games anymore but I can certainly state I don't regret purchasing this game two times since this account was created.

My nostalgia goggles are cracked.

Yes, this game was my childhood.  Yes, I miss the RTS genre.  Yes, I appreciate how much effort the developers have put into keeping the game going and coming up with new content.  But the AI is bad, the campaigns are exercises in frustration and anger management, and the factions are all using the same unit roster, so games get badly same-y no matter who you pick.

At some point you notice that you've sunk over a hundred hours into something you're not actually enjoying, and then you have to stop.

I have unreasonable nostalgia for this game. Unironically, one of the best tutorials in all of video games, the campaign. I love a good single-player mode in any game, and this one is great. plus there's so much expression of skill, through what gets micromanaged and how well, how robust the economy and positioning is throughout the map - this game has a lot of refinement, is what I'm trying to see. It's a very complex game, and learning the ins and outs, perfecting your craft, all that stuff - it's a challenge to learn it all and implement it into gameplay. It's a challenge to get good at it.

Then again I never played competitively, I'm afraid of interacting with people. so I'm not that good at the game lol.

still. I love the atmosphere, the music is iconic, and I get a fresh hit of dopamine when i hear that melee clanging sound. this is a big comfort game for me, maybe the biggest. all the other ones I know, my old pokemon games, and zelda, and the whole library of super nintendo games my older brother pirated when i was younger, all of those are. just. not in my hands anymore. Nintendo's squeezed pokemon so hard it feels completely different from when i was little, and hell, the new Link and Zelda are their own characters. I even like them, that's the thing. And all the assorted snes games are packaged behind nintendo's own shop. there's this... ugly membrane of choices that all make engaging with them feel... bitter. hollow.

Age of Empires 2 changed a little too. not much. not so dramatically. the meta seems to have shifted? I hear? but at its core, this is still that same game. It feels like a place beyond time, beyond age and death and worry. I'm a nervous lady. change makes me nervous. the whole world feels like it's changing for the worse, all the time, and every little detail that I don't like about new things in those old franchises... feels wrong. Age of Empires, it's always there. still the same solid stone, still telling these old tales and serving the same beer.

That's the feeling i have for this game. A warm welcome from old friends and neighbors, in a cozy inn with a roaring fire. It tastes like mom's cooking, it smells like my childhood room, it feels like being home again.

That said, I really think this isn't a game for everyone. I think that if you don't have the inclination to micromanage things, handle pressure and respond fast in a fight, you might not like this game. If you don't like forgetting what you wanted to do because you got distracted (like i do sometimes), you might not have fun. it's not the most forgiving game in the world, and there's a lot to learn. If that doesn't sound like your cup of tea, i don't blame you.

but with all that said.
if you do wanna give the game a try, I'll be there with a warm welcome for our newest member of the community. no pressure!

Currently we have:
- A toxic community that won't admit it
- "Low population"
- Outdated ELO/MMR/Rank system
- No penalty for those who resign early or on purpose to troll
- No penalty for trolls
- No penalty for toxic people
- The same 4 maps for every rotation and the rest that nobody plays/resigns after the match starts
- The pathfinding of a blind turtle
- A report system that doesn't work
- And much more 11

You may give the argument of; "it's an old game, you should be happy it's still alive", and to that I say: 
It's a product, and I payed for features like a decent ranked system as well as a report feature that enables me and others to report those that are toxic and/or cheat, and these don't work.

The only way I would recommend this game is if you have 2 or 3 friends that are going to play with you each time you boot up aoe2, or if you like a single player rts.

Played a lot as a kid, rebought it as an adult. Imagine getting to go back to 1999 when this game came out and start again. Avoid Covid-19, prevent elections you don't like, save loved ones, prevent crimes. Well you can't but you can get the Roman Empire DLC like I did and continue to think about the Roman Empire everyday.

Edit: After several years, the issues from before have been fixed. There is still the occasional unit not following orders, but on the whole, this game is in a much better state than it was. Some of the newer content is reused from the original game, which I ended up finding as more of an easter egg than an issue. Plus, with the addition of the original (piecemeal, anyway) I enjoy having the first two games in one place. 

Somehow, this game made the path finding for units worse. They get stuck on each other like the original Age of Empires (I), and they don't follow orders. This has made it almost impossible to effectively do anything, accurately. They attack the closest unit, more often than not, and the formations won't respond, which made some of the challenge missions in Sun Tzu impossible to complete properly. Not only that, but the game has crashed on me multiple times during campaigns, and I usually don't save because I've never needed to. Health bars won't display properly, and most of the "pretty" graphics don't even work. AoEII HD is a far superior product, and the addition of new civilizations doesn't nearly make up for it. Furthermore, the AI very clearly cheats, which, if I recall, was something the devs said they got rid of. But I tested it in two separate campaign scenarios, and the AI responds to my movements before it could have seen what I was doing. This was a good game, but DE has turned a good game into a poor game.

[h1]A great remaster of an old classic.[/h1]
The new updated visuals are great and the quality of life changes are much appreciated. The new voice acting for the single player campaigns are pretty hit or miss thought. The in-game modding menu is a good addition to the game. The achievements are much more enjoyable to hunt down compared to the awful ones from the 2013 [HD] Version.

You can get it at 20 ‚Ç¨/$, which to be honest, is a fair price, but you could also wait for a sale to get it (it now goes for 5‚Ç¨/$ which is an absolute steal). This is hands down the best way to experience AoE II to date. It includes the original Age of Kings, The Conquerors, Forgotten Empires, African Kingdoms, Rise of the Raja and the new [exclusive to DE] Last Khans expansions. 

Wholeheartedly recommend it, and make sure to check out the DLCs as well.

Age of Empires is one the best strategy games series of all time. The four games (I,II,III,Mythology) are very unique in their own and each are worth taking a look at. AOE II is best know for it's amazing play style, the amount of love put into each civilization and the historically campaigns. I finally got over 100 hours into this game, most of it in less than the previous 2 weeks. I needed to rack up some hours with this game after having more than 300 from the HD edition. If you're looking for someone who knows their way into it, and have been for a while, I can tell you all about it.

[h1]What the hell is an Age of Empires?[/h1]
For starters into the series, let me give you a quick overview. Age of Empires is an RTS series that revolves around you picking certain civilizations to play on certain maps. These civilizations have certain things that make them unique to one another. In the case of Age of Empires 2, there are these differences:
[list]
 [*][h3]Bonuses[/h3] Includes anything that might help you in your game, even includes things that your teammates can use. I say [i]might[/i] because some are trade offs, but just know it's what makes them unique.
 [*][h3]Unique Units[/h3]Basically units only a certain civilization can make. Some are good against certain units, others are good against others. Some need to be massed to be effective, some are fine going solo against a swarm. Of course, you can go the whole game without making them, but it's an option to have.
 [*][h3]Unique Techs[/h3]Things you can throw resources at in-game to give you an advantage over your foes. They usually come much later in the game, but they can make you units not only more powerful, but more [b]uniquely[/b] powerful.
[*][h3]Tech Tree[/h3]The game simply won't allow you to normally make every unit and get every upgrade in the game. If you're looking to make powerful mounted riders [i]and[/i] powerful archers, it's so rare, that I haven't come across an actual example. This makes you prefer certain unit types, and you need a plan to fully utilize your civilization.
[/list]
Now, why did I rattle off a bunch of stuff most fans of this game series already know about? Because this is what makes Age of Empires 2 that much more re-playable and fun. There are about 30 or so civilizations in the game, with arguably a large amount of strategy you can try with each civilization, from early archer rush, to a fast castle into knights, with a similarly variable amount of effectiveness, not to mention the skill of each individual player! It's dizzying to even think about them!
As a fan of strategy games, like the Total War series, and the Paradox grand strategy games, playing just Age of Empires 2 is a pleasure to have, and I look forward to the many hours that will come with it.

[h2]Why Definitive Edition?[/h2]
This is more to those who are either players from the HD edition, or those who are considering buying this over the HD edition, and vice versa. As a fan since playing the Forgotten Empires DLC way back in 2015 (and arguably much earlier if you read my HD review), here are some things that make DE worth every penny, even if you already own the HD edition and its DLCs like I did.
[olist]
[*][h3]Genuine quality-of-life improvements[/h3]My favourite, these are things that make the game either much more accessible, or make the pros be even more pro. They're too long to list, but some game-play ones are queuing up technologies (plural) after units and vice versa, selecting all buildings of a certain type, auto-scouting (though some might disagree), queuing up villager or military actions, and much more! 
This also includes bug fixes which makes the HD edition the equivalent of an unkempt attic.
[*][h3]Regular updates[/h3]I love games which not only fix bugs, but regularly update the game. They don't even have to introduce something new, just regular tweaking and changing is mostly good enough. In fact, the aforementioned civilizations are objectively better compared to HD because of the next point.
[*][h3]Civilization balance[/h3]In the HD edition, players used to really get riled up over certain civilizations because they are just that good, and don't get me started on the Age of Conquerors edition. I never liked Hun wars. With the Definitive Edition, now all the civilizations mostly stand a chance against each other, because of regular balance changes. 
The buffs, nerfs, and even trade offs regularly introduced are very welcome. If you don't believe me, go to aoestats.io and see how many civilizations near 50% in their win rate. If anything, it makes the HD edition's lack of updates just that much sadder.
[*][h3]New content[/h3]Ignoring the paid DLCs, the Definitive Edition itself came with a "free DLC" in the form of the Last Khans. This introduces 4 new civilizations and 3 new campaigns. 
While it doesn't explicitly say in the store page, the campaigns from the Forgotten Empires DLC were also reworked, in very major ways, making them more streamlined and fun, and less novelty scenarios. When I mean novelty, I meant turning Age of Empires 2 to a stealth mission in the Sforza campaign. 
I know this because I actually played the Forgotten Empires campaign. [b]I'm serious![/b] Go to my profile and see my achievements for the HD edition. Theoretically, this sets DE further from the HD edition, and is yet more content that comes with the game!
[*][h3]Graphics, sounds, and superficial changes[/h3]The game just looks, sounds, and feels better. This edition is no Warcraft 3: Reforged, and is far more than a graphical remake. Yet, the better graphics, reworked music (which I love quite a bit), and even much better UI make your experience with this much better.
[/olist]
Unless you insist on playing the older versions, like friends exclusively on Voobly, the Definitive Edition really is the superior of them. I did not regret spending every penny on it, and neither should you, so I highly recommend getting it!

I've played the original Age of Kings and Conquerors back when I was 5 years old. It's been a childhood favorite, and this version is the perfect update to the previous, removing most of the multiplayer desyncs prevalent in HD edition, removing paladins moving two frames per second when chasing raiding parties, and separated ranked and unranked scores to accommodate casual play. 

The devs provide consistent updates for balancing civilizations and addressing bugs, and combined and expanded on all of the HD edition DLCs with new ones as well, on top of including the original campaigns from both Age of Kings and Conquerors back in 1999 and 2000, respectfully, with modern tweaks (to mixed effect). 

The game is best played with friends in team matches, unless you like to sweat a lot in 1v1s, but thankfully, it's not hard to make friends here. 

10/10, would recommend.

People, especially those just interested in single player, sometimes ask whether you should get Definitive Edition or HD edition from 2013. Or perhaps they already have the 2013 HD edition and ask why should they "repurchase" the game as a Definitive Edition.

To say that Age of Empires II Definitive Edition is the same game as Age of Empires II HD edition (that came out in 2013) just with some better graphics doesnt do it justice. Let's talk about the graphics first. If you have a good computer, you can download the HD textures pack which allows you to dynamically zoom in and out by rolling your mouse wheel and truly admire the detail of every single unit and every single building. Even back when I was a kid in the early 2000s, I actually loved playing Age of Empires II at 800x600 resolution than the standard of 1280x1024 5:4 aspect ratio back in the day, because the buildings looked bigger and more zoomed in, even if they got a bit blurrier. I never liked playing Aoe 2 on high resolutions because then, everything became tiny and you'd lose immersion. 2013's HD edition tied the resolution to your monitor's native res with no way of changing it internally in the game menu, so if you wanted a more zoomed in view, you'd have to manually change your desktop resolution before launching the game. Tedious. So Definitive edition's dynamic zoom capability is a big service to all those who appreciate detail. On top of that, you can zoom in quite far before the graphics get blurry, so there's plenty of new detail to admire. Sadly, the game doesn't allow you to play like this as there's a lot of stuff going on and in a real time RTS you have to manage your economy and react quickly to threats elsewhere.

Now let's talk about the 2nd reason why Definitive Edition is an improvement over HD edition. Not only has Definitive Edition revoiced every single campaign (granted, i preferred the old voices to the new ones) and reworked every single campaign slide artwork (for better or for worse, at least the new drawing style remains consistent throughout all campaigns while 2013's HD edition came with Microsoft's 1999 Age of Kings and 2000 The Conqueror's artstyles mixed with a crudely drawn new artstyle for the Forgotten empires, and then a more refined one for African kingdoms + Rise of the rajas) and on top of that, Definitive Edition has also voiced all the Forgotten empires campaigns that only had textslides in the HD edition, gives you 3 new campaigns (Kotyan Khan, Ivaylo, and Tamerlane), 1 new architecture style (steppe / central asian), and finally all paid DLC factions and architecture styles that were released later, are given free to the AI factions encountered in the base game's campaigns, so you also get to see new Bohemian and Polish architecture e.g. when you're fighting the eastern european factions in the Mongol campaign, even if you haven't purchased the DLC that would then allow you to play as or against them in random maps or play their faction specific campaigns.

So for me for example, replaying the Forgotten empires campaigns with narrated slides and in-game voiced dialogue was definitely a treat, although they removed the El Dorado campaign and replaced it with a new one called Pachacuti where you also play as the Incas but with completely different missions. And they also changed some missions that were heavily scripted and felt more like an RPG than an RTS scenario. So yes, the Forgotten campaigns did lose some of their complexity and uniqueness and got more streamlined, but are still fun to play.

The AI is also very good. The 2013 HD edition AI sucked; it built no walls but 20 towers and tried to swarm you with units and resigned the moment you destroyed its TC. It was so unfun to play against that I instead played with the 1999 Age of Kings CD A.I. but on hard difficulty. In Definitive Edition i play with the new AI on moderate and it feels engaging but not overwhelming.

And finally this is obviously the game with the most active multiplayer community, with all the new story driven DLCs from Dawn of the Dukes to Dynasties of India, new factions, new building sets, new units, and even Age of Empires I and Rise of Rome's factions have been ported over in a separate paid expansion pack game mode, so seriously, what are you waiting for?

What else can be said about such a timeless classic? I do think there's no better RTS game out there, so come and fight me.

Now, talking seriously, Age 2 is a must if you're looking to get into the RTS genre. There's so much replayability in this and the balance is tight for you to pick up a civ and try to win the game. Playing this game is an absolute treat, everything from the base building, to the combat system, to the upgrade/age advancement system is a finely tuned machine that Ensemble Studios developed since the OG Age 2.

And if you ever get tired of playing hardcore PVP matches you can always find people running scenarios in MP, things like "Choose your hero RPG" or "Castle Blood Alliance" or "Survive the Dinosaurs". Age 2 got you covered, and there will never be enough reasons for me to not recommend such a gem.

also, the inclusion of the "Return of Rome" with all the original races of the first age of empires and its expansion (along with one new race) truly makes my experience to hit a nostalgia climax...(lol) 
I do recommend the base Definitive medieval part for the people that loved the original cd version some eons ago, but I would also recommended the new RoR dlc for the people that also played the original of AoE some more eons ago, to switch between them at any given time, in-game. The Experience of RoR dlc is rather an Age of Empires 1.5 Definitive Edition, which,  for me, its really fun to play with.
The addition of Rome faction (I guess you could say the western part of it) in the medieval part of the game was something that I could never expect, and it was a nice surprise.
Lastly, also the addition of two new original campaigns and some of the old original campaigns of the 90's AoE and RoR was also a mixed modern/nostalgia fun, if I can say that....

Age of Empires II - 8/10

This game is often hailed as one of the greatest ever created, and I wholeheartedly concur with that sentiment. Age of Empires II masterfully combines elements of combat, city construction, defense management, and resource handling, making it a truly enjoyable gaming experience. In this edition, the game has received a visual overhaul, with updated sprites that add to the overall enjoyment. Much like many computer games from the early 2000s, the sprite style evokes a sense of nostalgia and artistic charm.

Age of Empires II offers a rich array of gameplay options, including multiplayer matches, single-player skirmishes, immersive campaigns, and a scenario editor, ensuring that players have the potential to spend countless hours in the game's captivating world. The combat mechanics are straightforward and easy to grasp, involving the creation and enhancement of troops, as well as their placement and garrisoning. Players have the flexibility to adjust unit positioning, aggression levels, and guard duties, which extends to naval combat as well.

Admittedly, combat can become somewhat repetitive over time, and managing city defenses can be a bit bothersome, but this is, after all, a war simulation. Such challenges only serve to enhance the authenticity of the experience, making Age of Empires II a timeless classic in the realm of strategy gaming.

Overall:
Gameplay: 8/10
Graphics & Presentation: 9/10
Replay-ability & Content: 10/10

Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition is a nostalgia trip that hits all the right notes. If you've ever spent countless hours building empires and waging epic battles in the original 1999 classic, this one's for you.

Nostalgia Revived:
The graphics have received a major facelift, but the game's heart and soul remain intact. It's like meeting an old friend who's had an amazing makeover but hasn't lost their essence. Reliving classic scenarios in glorious detail is an absolute blast.

Classic Gameplay, Modern Flair:
Age of Empires II's addictive blend of resource management and strategic warfare is as gripping as ever. The devs have sprinkled some modern magic with improved UI and pathfinding, making it accessible to new players while preserving its legendary gameplay.

A Few Hiccups:
The one downside is the change in voiceovers for the original campaigns. The old voices had character, and their absence is felt. It's a small gripe in an otherwise stellar package.

In summary, Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition is a must-have for fans old and new. It's a nostalgic trip that feels fresh and exciting, with just a minor hiccup along the way. If you've ever dreamt of commanding empires through history, this is your chance to do it all over again, and it's better than ever.

There was an update a little while ago that caused the game to stop working for everyone not on Windows. (Linux, Steam Deck, Mac‚Ä¶) Last time I checked, there were a couple methods to fix it. I tried one (on Linux) and it didn‚Äôt work. I uninstalled the game, thinking that reinstalling might help, but‚Ä¶ I just don‚Äôt feel like clicking that install button anymore.

Since that particular update, I‚Äôve learned some things about the game. Frankly, the more I learn about the game, the more I regret buying it.

Apparently, local multiplayer doesn‚Äôt work without an internet connection, which defeats the point of local multiplayer. Apparently, many people have experienced game-breaking bugs. (The bugs seem to be related to DLC. I never bought any of the DLC, and I never experienced such serious bugs.) Apparently, DLC civs are overpowered and destroy game balance. The events that make this feel like a mobile game are unnecessary and ridiculous.
