A neat game, that's quite fun to play with your friends as a time-passer and it's a way to have some decent fun.
However, it's incredibly unbalanced when it comes to its single-player campaigns, which are either way too easy or - more often than not - impossibly difficult, rendering the entire single-player experience a regrettable incident. But, then again, it's microsoft, so I guess it's pretty typical for them to suck at their own game.

As such, I'd recommend this game only on sale and only if you loved it back in the day, when the game was in its prime. But, overall, I am not that convinced anyone can still have fun with this one. Some 20 years ago, maybe. But not now.

I was not expecting that out of old great rts games this will turn out to be the most popular 20 years down the road, but it totally deserves the spot! 
Age of Empires 2 always felt better/more fun for me than clunky Broodwar or low-cost Warlords Battlecry, maybe Warcraft 3 could surpass it but it was rts of a different kind, more micro/rpg focused so it doesn't count.
AoE 2 is pure macro focused rts and it's best of its kind! I always loved  increased number of resources compared to blizzard games and randomly generated maps that let you adapt! 
Getting better at the games feels very satisfying  and even ai gives a lot of challange and room for improvement, Im just mastering hard ai on arabia after 100h! 
I found Definitive Edition to add some very helpful QoL features like que commands, easy shortcuts, small trees that make gameplay far easier than in old days and I really like it! 
Only problem I have with the game is unfortunately,  not the best pathfinding  of units, other than that...no complains.

Positives: 
1. This game is a blast from the past with a ton of fixes that players have been asking for for years.  

2. The multiplayer maps are a blast, and the new campaigns look gorgeous.  

3. New factions are being added at a relatively frequent pace.


Negatives:

1. Some of the newer campaigns have a very disturbing trend of having the AI cheat so that you will play the game exactly the same way that the game makers want you to, rather than giving you the chance to explore and try new and innovative ways to beat the missions.  I am not talking about the ai having ludicrous amounts of money, troops, or other surmountable perks.  I am referring almost unkillable troops.  These forces heal so fast that they are almost impossible to kill.  They heal fast enough that you need 4-5 powerful units attacking each and every single one at the same time in order to maybe kill it.  Those units are placed en mass on various maps, and it sucks all of the fun out of those missions.  I will never replay those missions unless those ridiculous stats are removed from all units.

2. Lazy campaign making.  Aside from the invulnerable units, a trend has appeared where enemies just spawn en mass in parts of the map rather than "marching" from the edge of the map, which is only a gate or two lengths away to their desired formation/location.


Conclusion: If you play this game primarily for the multiplayer purposes, I highly suggest getting this game when it and all of its expansion packs are on sale.  If you are wanting to play for the campaigns, skip it.  This is not worth playing unless they take all of the cheating out of everything.  I see that as being likely as a pet squirrel learning how to play the banjo well.

This was my childhood, and I am so glad it is still true to itself

I read the negative reviews, but took a chance, my view is the game is SO WORTH IT (for $5 on the steam sale it better be OUTSTANDING for a positive review, lol).

The visuals are a stunning improvement (you figure they better be with 20 years in between titles, and they are)...

The menu options are SO MUCH MORE INTUITIVE from the original...I have been playing this game off and on for 24 years now since it came out...(and playing AOE1 before that - yeah I know that game was not as good)...simple things like a mill that gives you the option to AUTO rebuild farms = a HUGE POSITIVE, that you can see how many troops are in a group with an actual # (so when attacking you can see how you are fairing), it gives you a grid ONLY when building so you can see how much spacing between buildings is another HUGE POSITIVE, the LUDICROUS map option which is SO MUCH BIGGER THAN the largest size on the original AOE2 is great for those who LOVE LARGE MAPS...being able to click on a group to easily find them (as the numbers of your groups are at the bottom of the screen...also helps you identify if a group got taken out...

The visuals are awesome, where you see buildings on fire, how they implode when destroyed...

The game is $5 on steam sale right now...I do not work for the company, I just love video games and this game is SO MUCH BETTER than the original which was awesome...including a NON-NARRATION video of some HIGHLIGHTS of my first play thru on STANDARD 1v1 vs the AI...check it out...I plan to post other videos of the game over the next bit as it is such a great game!  :)

MY 1st HIGHLIGHTS of the game VIDEO IS HERE (with no narration ... I plan to post more on my channel in the coming days/weeks/months...): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PQP5RxW9NuY

PS:  Oh yeah, one last thing about the ONLY issue with the game...the narrator of the game SUCKS...a SIMPLE FIX to shut him up...press the GEARS at the top of the screen when it first starts, AUDIO, where is says any narration uncheck...you are welcome.  :)  

Trust me the game is worth it and do not let that tiny annoyance sway you from trying out an amazing upgrade of an amazing game

PPS:  I do NOT have any of the DLCs...I use the Byzantines...so no clue if the DLCs change any aspect of the game as I have not bothered with them yet...

This game holds a special place for me in my memories, a childhood classic for me.

I've been playing this game for well over a decade, and I was so excited when the DE released. The graphics enhancement was great! I played it a lot and was able to play on extreme difficulty fairly easily. 

Unfortunately, the recent updates are just so awful. The pathing is absolutely terrible. Trying to get your units through gates is a nightmare when it used to be so easy. When you invade an enemy town your units just endlessly chase enemy trade carts which is just stupid. Whenever you command your trebuchets to attack a castle, they unpack and then just sit there and do not attack anything. Your boats will be getting attacked and instead of attacking back, they prioritize killing an enemy house or something. Every update it seems like there is always a small change that just makes the game worse. It's been like this for months, and there are more problems that I did not mention.

I'm so bummed because I love this game, but it really feels like instead of fighting the enemy you are battling your own units. I just played a game on hardest instead of extreme, and it was so difficult due to all of the above mentioned problems. It was so so frustrating. I can't imagine playing this game again until they make necessary changes.
It's a classic, what more is there to say?

The game did not withstand the test of time. It's a popular RTS because of nostalgia and there are not many other options. Does that make it a great game? Definitely not.

Too many hotkeys. I think there can be a better setup for the controls. Developers think not.
AI is still very bad, another important aspect of the game that was barely improved.

Annoying fundaments. For example you need to build houses for workers. Five workers per house. You will be building 40 houses to reach 200 population. Genius developers!

Pathing is still terrible, for some reason. You click army to go back, they go forward then back. You click your villagers to get food, they walk away from the food then towards it.

Too many research options, easy to forget something during the battle. Simple setup would be good, and would allow less time thinking about research and more time to guide armies.

One example of research being facepalm, when you need militia late game they need many upgrades before they are relevant, this means barracks and also blacksmith upgrades. 

Unbalanced maps. Mirrored maps would solve this rather easily and give fair balancing.

Too easy to troll with some factions, if you have played ranked before then you know this.

The game did not get better with the time, it stayed where it was while time moved forward.

The game really is not good. The only reason the reviews are so high is because this game caters to a tiny niche population of people that play the game religiously.
In order to win games, you have to study different aspects of the game. It's not based on skill, but on knowledge about the game's mechanics. 

There are multiple types of not only regular units, but also special units unique to each civ that counter each other. You have to know what each one does, what it's weak against, and what it's strong against. Each civ also has different bonuses. Better make some flashcards. 

Have you ever heard of a build order? In this game, you have to memorize different ways to organize your villagers. If you do one little thing wrong in the early game, it will be bye bye for you every time in the late game. In order to even have a chance at winning, you have to follow this order down to the bone, destroying any wish you had of creativity. 

Not only that, sometimes the map you spawn on will have one crucial resource far away from your town center for the enemy to camp. 

Following this, you must spam all of your resources into one unit type and always have your military buildings working. At this point, it's basically rock paper scissors. If you choose the wrong initial unit to make and finally figure out that the enemy chose your counter, it's already too late. 

Once you figured out that you lost the rock paper scissors match, you can resign or keep playing until you eventually lose. The enemy will type something toxic in the chat 75% of the time after this because the community is horrible.
You will dream, eat, and breath this game

So, another case where I have to change my review for a game I love(d) because the devs treat their playerbase like sh!t.

This was an absolutely excellent remake of AoE2, and it plays as great as ever and looks glorious. However, the devs have been continuously pushing the game to become a mOdErN gAmInG multiplayer button-smasher and ignoring how godawful and robotic the skirmish AI is (which is either infuriating to play against, or extremely buggy and dumb on most non-default game settings). You will get popups about ranked map voting or whatever even if you never touched the multiplayer button, but whole sections of single player just don't work and don't even seen to be on any roadmap.

Even better? They are adding NEW bugs with new updates. The Return of Rome DLC was not only released in a barely functioning state with broken single player, its bugs actually spilled into the main game. So yes, in 2023 you have AoE2: Definitive Edition which in many ways works worse than on release, or the 1999 version of the game. They also frequently break basic mechanics like pathfinding or now even how hard it is to select units/buildings (seriously) with new updates, as if they never did any basic testing.

This is a brilliant game and a brilliant remake. But its current state is genuinely bad, and the devs are actively and blatantly ignoring >90% of their playerbase. The amazing campaigns *should* still work great, but you never know if they still will after the next update reworks Arabia and Extreme difficulty for the 20th time and introduces 10 new bugs for everyone else.

This is not a good time to play AoE2:DE, and the devs seriously DO NOT deserve your money right now.

EDIT: I'll add more because each time I try to get back into it, the more pissed off I get. It genuinely seems like the devs at some point decided to ruin everything what made this game groundbreaking in the first place (influencing everything from Stronghold to Total War) and make it as caveman as they could.

Units walking in formations? Not the AIs, you're literally fighting a swarm of annoying flies who walk and attack you separately from 23446 directions at once or like an endless stream of diarrhea, like in AoE1 cranked to parody levels. (After playing this, it feels so weird to launch AoE3 and see enemies attack you with ARMIES and not swarms of flies.) Each and every single one of them can dodge projectiles separately, of course! And it's easy to check this was not how it used to be - the game still has the "CD version AI" which while clearly very dated and not clever, HAS ARMIES WALK IN FORMATIONS. IN 1999.

More elaborate defences - walls, gates, castles and several types of towers? They've done pretty much everything possible to make defensive play difficult and as unrewarding as possible, when THIS WAS LITERALLY THE RTS GAME which showed that RTS can have real defensive options.

Better pathfinding and units that aren't complete morons? I swear it's getting worse and worse and units require more micromanagement than ever so they don't either idle with a battle raging 2 metres away or go Leeroy Jenkins into a bunch of enemy castles after one archer. Don't even get me started on trying to use mangonels and not get your units killed.

Fuck this. This is embarrassing. The state of this game right now is like seeing the Pyramids or Notre Dame turned into a McDonalds. I can't believe that they've managed to bring this to a point where I HATE playing one of my favourite games of all time.

Very on point that they're merging with Activision, this is exactly the type of murdering a legendary game they specialize in. Warcraft, Diablo and Call of Duty are welcoming a new member to the club, I guess.

1. Factions being varied but still similar enough is nice.

3. Multiplayer elo starts way too high. Should start around 300 so you can play with people who aren't just meta-gaming.

5. Campaigns are very buggy. Expect to be constantly softlocked because you went off exploring too early and broke an event trigger.
6. Has lots of different AIs that each have their own styles of play and difficulty.
7. The AI seems to be actually playing the same game you are. It doesn't seem to cheat much if at all beyond knowing where you are. If this was a Creative Assembly game the AI would always have resources regardless and just spam out units it shouldn't be able to afford.
8. Longbows are neat.

As of the latest patch, this game is an obnoxious mess. The pathing is totally broken, melee units will not be able to find a fight that is logical, ranged units path as bad as the infantry, Siege will not work out a viable path when they need to go straight. villager shift queues no longer work, their pathing is atrocious. 
Forgotten Empires seem keen on messing with the pathing and continually making it worse, they do not seem to make any clear communication about why it's so temperamental and now it's got to the stage where you struggle to enjoy a match. That's if you're one of th elucky ones who doesn't get BSODs due to this patch and it's recent "hotfix".
If you're thinking of getting this game right now, Don't do it. Forgotten Empires need to sort out what the hell is going on over there, stop throwing DLC at the game and actually fix the problems that have been problems since release.
How they got the job is beyond me at this point.

[h1]This game ranks number 1 for the number of hours I spent in any single playthrough.[/h1]
[quote][b]Rating:[/b] 8.5/10[/quote]
One of the most bang-for-buck games. I only played the single-player campaign and this is my first and only RTS game. I almost never play any 2D game, but this game made me give it an exemption.

In this Real Time Strategy game, we start our journey by building the economy and growing our army. Sometimes we try diplomacy and find allies while we get new enemies. We conquer the city by completing assigned objectives which mostly involve destroying enemy bases. 

The story and voiceover are serviceable but not much worth a story. The gameplay is what people love this game for.

Although inefficient, I find it super fun to just overpower my enemy by building a very huge army and sending all of them at once as a "surprise" return gift for all the small attacks they do in my base, meanwhile, I do villain laughs seeing their base being ripped apart by my army and they unable to produce enough soldiers to match mine xD

It's a very fun game, single player content alone is extremely huge, and then multiplayer is another thing.

Easy recommendation.

A Timeless Classic Reinvented - Age Of Empires II: Definitive Edition

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê (5/5) - Recommended!

Age Of Empires II: Definitive Edition is the epitome of a timeless classic that continues to captivate and enchant players of all ages. As a long-time fan of the franchise, I can confidently say that this remastered version is an absolute masterpiece, and it comes with numerous reasons why it's highly recommended for both veterans and newcomers alike.

1. A Trip Down Memory Lane, Remastered: Age Of Empires II holds a special place in the hearts of many gamers, and this Definitive Edition delivers a beautiful and faithful remastering of the original game. The developers have managed to maintain the core essence of the classic while giving it a fresh coat of paint with stunning 4K graphics, enhanced audio, and smoother gameplay.

2. An Immersive Historical Experience: If you have a passion for history, Age Of Empires II: DE offers an unparalleled experience. The game's campaigns take you on a journey through different epochs, allowing you to lead powerful civilizations such as the Britons, Mongols, Teutons, and many others. The attention to historical accuracy and the abundance of educational content make it an engaging and enriching experience for history enthusiasts.

3. Strategic Depth and Variety: One of the main reasons why Age Of Empires II: DE has stood the test of time is its rich and complex gameplay. From managing resources and economy to creating diverse military units and devising unique strategies, the game offers countless possibilities. Each civilization has its strengths and weaknesses, ensuring that every playthrough is a fresh and rewarding challenge.

4. Active Community and Ongoing Support: The Age Of Empires II community is a welcoming and passionate group of players. The developers have demonstrated an unwavering commitment to the game's support, regularly releasing updates, bug fixes, and even new content, keeping the experience fresh and enjoyable.

5. Extensive Multiplayer and Customization Options: The multiplayer aspect of Age Of Empires II: DE is incredibly robust. Whether you want to engage in intense 1v1 duels or participate in large-scale team battles, there's a mode for every preference. Furthermore, the game offers extensive modding support, allowing the community to create and share their unique scenarios, maps, and modifications, adding virtually limitless content.

6. Intuitive User Interface and Enhanced Mechanics: The developers have made significant improvements to the user interface, making it more intuitive and user-friendly, even for newcomers to the real-time strategy genre. They've also added quality-of-life features that streamline gameplay without sacrificing the game's complexity.

In conclusion, Age Of Empires II: Definitive Edition is a testament to the lasting legacy of this iconic franchise. It's a game that welcomes both veterans and newcomers with open arms, offering an immersive historical experience, strategic depth, and a supportive community. Whether you're a fan of the original or new to the series, this remastered version is an absolute must-play. I can wholeheartedly recommend Age Of Empires II: DE to anyone looking for a rewarding and enjoyable gaming experience.

For those who have played older releases of this game and enjoyed it, Definitive Edition is a definite 'yes.'  It fixes a lot of quality-of-life issues that help Age of Empires II hold up under modern standards, while not changing anything too core to the game's feel.
-----
For those new to Age of Empires II, this is definitely the version to get.  I'll warn you though, that while it may be refurbished very well, this is still an RTS from the '90s, so it has a lot of obscure mechanics and unintuitive "jank."  Long-time players will be used to all that, but it's probably uninviting for newcomers.  If you're just messing around with your friends, or doing singleplayer, that probably won't matter to you as much, but if your eyes are on the ranked ladder, it might feel unapproachable.  The decades worth of expansions, while great, only increase the overwhelming amount of unit interactions you need to be aware of.  However, if you're into nerding out about technicalities and analyzing tracked statistics, this game will offer a lot to sink your teeth into, and there are whole communities dedicated to that.

If you like this game's premise, but the thought of "deep jank" sounds unappealing, you might enjoy Age of Empires IV instead: a more modern take on this same series with a greater focus on being approachable.
-----
Whether you're new or old, the fact that this game is still receiving a constant stream of free updates and paid expansions after 25 years is a testament to how much staying power it has.  A mediocre game does not stir that kind of dedication in people.

Age of Empires 2 is a game that beautifully embraces simplicity. It offers an accessible yet deep gaming experience.

The gameplay is straightforward: build your empire, gather resources, train armies, and conquer opponents. This simplicity, combined with strategic depth, strikes a perfect balance.

Attention to detail is remarkable. Each civilization is historically accurate, with unique strengths and playstyles that add depth to the game.

Gameplay is excellent, with intuitive controls and a user-friendly interface. The AI opponents provide challenging matches.

The multiplayer component allows for epic battles and cooperative gameplay, with a vibrant online community.

Despite not having modern graphics, the art style remains visually appealing. The music and sound design enhance immersion.

Age of Empires 2 is a masterpiece in the real-time strategy genre, offering accessible gameplay, historical accuracy, and superb execution. A must-have for gamers.

Age of Empires ll is an absolute gem in the realm of real-time strategy games. With it's captivating gameplay, rich historical setting, and remarkable attention to detail, it offers an immersive experience that keeps players coming back for more.

One of the games greatest strengths lies in its diverse civilizations, each with unique units, technologies, and architectural styles. Whether you're commanding the mighty Mongols, the cunning Britons, or the formidable Teutons, there's a civilization that suits every player's preferred playstyle.

The strategic depth of Age of Empires ll is unparalleled. From carefully managing your economy to executing well-timed military campaigns, every decision you make can have a profound impact on the outcome of the game. The balance between resource gathering, building structures, and engaging in warfare creates an addictive gameplay loop that keeps you engrossed for hours.

The attention to historical accuracy is commendable. From the authentic unit design to the historical inspired campaigns, the game allows players to delve into the past and relive epic battles and conquests. It's not only entertaining but also educational, offering a window into different eras and civilizations.

Age of Empires ll boasts a strong multiplayer community that adds another layer of excitement. Whether you team up with friends to conquer opponents or challenge others in intense head-to-head matches, the multiplayer mode provides endless opportunities for strategic competition and camaraderie.

Furthermore, the game's visuals have aged gracefully. The hand painted graphics and intricate details still hold up, creating a visually pleasing experience. The iconic soundtrack perfectly complements the gameplay, immersing you further into the world of medieval warfare.

In conclusion, Age of Empires ll is a timeless classic that continues that captivate played with its strategic depth, historical authenticity, and engaging gameplay. Whether you're a long-time fan or new to the series, this game is a must play for anyone who appreciates the genre.

I grew up on the original game from 1999, and I loved it then. This remaster realized how good that one was, kept what made it so good, and revamped it to an even better standard, between modernizing for today's PCs, enhanced graphics, more civs to play from, and all the other knick-knacks that make it a viable game for the Steam platform.

You start the game with a small village and workers, and you build your way up the tech tree, while trying to accomplish your goal, whether it's a campaign objective, kill everyone else, maintain a wonder building for a period of time, etc.

I 110% recommend this game, if you're into RTS games (think Warcraft, Starcraft, Command and Conquer, Rise of Nations).

Another note to consider, you might see the same game, marked as HD Edition, which came out in the early 2010s, which is the same game as the original, but updated graphics and other novelties. This remaster, the Definitive Edition, which came out much later, is practically its own game, and gets treated as such, so you know which one to buy. They're both good, but this is the one I believe Microsoft will keep an eye on as far as updates, DLC, and maintenance goes.

Age of Empires II full review:

Age of Empires II is a classic real-time strategy game released in 1999 by Ensemble Studios. He has a dedicated fan base and a long history of success that has impacted many lives, including mine. I'll provide a comprehensive review covering various aspects of the game.

Deep gameplay: One of Age of Empires II's greatest strengths is its deep and immersive gameplay. The game lets players take control of historical civilizations and challenges them to build and expand their empire, collect resources, train armies and participate in epic battles. The variety of possible strategies and the complexity of the game mechanics ensure that each match is unique and stimulating.

Variety of Civilizations: Age of Empires II features a wide variety of playable civilizations, each with their own unique units, technologies, and advantages. From medieval Europeans to Middle Eastern and Asian peoples, the game's cultural diversity offers an educational and enriching experience, introducing players to different parts of the world and their histories.

Captivating Historical Campaigns: The game offers a series of well-researched historical campaigns that tell of important events and figures in history such as Joan of Arc, William the Conqueror, Genghis Khan and Saladin. These campaigns not only provide entertainment, but also spark an interest in historical events and can inspire players to learn more about the past.

Active community and expansions: Age of Empires II continues to be enjoyed and updated by the community to this day. The player community is active, creative and welcoming, and this is evident through forums, tournaments and custom content created by fans. The expansions released over the years such as The Conquerors, The Forgotten, African Kingdoms and Rise of the Rajas have added new civilizations, campaigns and features to the game, further enriching the experience.

Memorable Soundtrack: Age of Empires II's soundtrack is iconic and emotionally impactful. The songs evoke a sense of adventure, grandeur and medieval atmosphere. The quality of the soundtrack significantly contributes to the immersion in the game and becomes an unforgettable part of the experience.

For many, Age of Empires II was part of their lives and childhoods. The game not only provided entertainment and fun, but also stimulated interest in history and the development of strategic skills. The memories of long hours spent building empires, planning strategies and fighting epic battles with friends or against the computer are precious treasures that continue to be remembered fondly.

In summary, Age of Empires II is a real-time strategy game that has impacted many lives, including mine. Its deep gameplay, variety of civilizations, captivating historical campaigns, active community and memorable soundtrack all contribute to an enriching and lasting experience. It is a game that awakens interest in history and offers moments of fun and learning, leaving an indelible mark on the lives of many players.

New review: After playing the game for 1000 more hours, I have decided it is a good game.

I've been playing this game since it first came out on CD-ROM back in 1999 when I used to call up friends from school to see if they wanted to try and connect our dial-up modems and play a multiplayer game.  It's a lot easier than that now. And in fact the whole game has continued to be improved upon, added to, and polished to such a degree it overshadows all other entries in the series. There are more civilizations, game types, and campaigns than ever before. This really is the definitive edition of a top tier RTS and one of the all time greatest games.
Best game ever for RTSG

[b] Achievements. Many achievements.[/b]

[h1] The Game[/h1]
The Definitive Edition of one of the greatest real-time strategy games of all time. With many campaigns and multiplayer available, updated graphics and a remastered soundtrack this game offers a great experience for the fans of real-time strategy.

The story (or the campaigns for better wording) provide a lot of historical scenarios in different parts of the world. The problem is that it can become quite tedious to play through them all (as is the requirement for the achievements) with only some variation in the objectives. The visuals are quite alright that don't bring a massive and immersive experience but still look decent in 2023. The gameplay is centered around the standard of many RTS games: gather resources, build a base and produce military units. There is some variation between the different civilizations that alter the gameplay in (somewhat) different ways but the concept stays the same. 

[h1] The Achievements [/h1]
There are a lot of achievements and it will take quite some time to get them all. Luckily only a few are considered to be very hard and 1 multiplayer one (there is a discussion thread + a group that are dedicated for this so) with guides available for everything. DLC is required for 100% completion.

[h1] Recommendation [/h1]
I am on the verge of whether to recommend this or not to achievement hunters, unless you are a big fan of RTS games. I am personally a big fan of this game but it can very well take you over 200+ hours to finish all of the achievements. A recommendation is to see it as a longer "project" where you can play it more casually whenever you want as you play through all of the campaigns. Despite it become a bit tedious at times due to lack of variety in the different parts of the game I still consider it to be one of the better RTS-games out there (for achievement hunters).
